item.name: Pixie Dust
entries: As an action, you can sprinkle this dust on yourself or another creature you can see within 5 feet of you. The recipient gains a flying speed of 30 feet and the ability to hover for 1 minute. If the creature is airborne when this effect ends, it falls safely to the ground, taking no damage and landing on its feet.
A small packet holds enough pixie dust for one use.

item.name: Potion of Advantage
entries: When you drink this potion, you gain advantage on one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw of your choice that you make within the next hour.
This potion takes the form of a sparkling, golden mist that moves and pours like water.

item.name: Witchlight Vane
item.reqAttune: by a mister light or his handpicked successor
entries: This ornate rod is topped by a pair of butterfly wings and incorporates bits of red glass into its length. It weighs 3 pounds.

entries.name: Magic Weapon
entries: In the hands of one who is attuned to it, the vane can be wielded as a magic mace that grants a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it. In addition, the vane deals an extra {@damage 1d8} radiant damage on a hit.

entries.name: Sense Mood
entries: While the vane is inside the perimeter of the Witchlight Carnival, it can sense the mood of every creature in the carnival that has an Intelligence of 4 or higher. As an action, a creature attuned to the vane can use it to pinpoint the location of the happiest creature in the carnival.

The butterfly shape at the top of the vane spins slowly clockwise when spirits in the carnival are generally high; if the general mood in the carnival is dour, the top of the vane spins slowly counterclockwise.

entries.name: Sentience
entries: The vane is a sentient, chaotic good wondrous item with an Intelligence of 11, a Wisdom of 14, and a Charisma of 14. It has hearing and normal vision out to a range of 30 feet, and it communicates by transmitting emotion to the creature attuned to it. Its purpose is to make sure everyone in the Witchlight Carnival is having a good time.

entries.name: Additional Properties
entries: The vane has the following additional properties:

items: The creature holding the vane has vulnerability to lightning damage.
The creature attuned to the vane can't be {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition petrified}, or {@condition stunned}.

While carrying the vane, the creature attuned to it can cast the {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell polymorph}, or {@spell ray of frost} spell as an action, requiring no spell components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability. After the vane's {@spell polymorph} spell is cast, roll a {@dice d8}; on a roll of 3 or 8, the vane can't be used to cast this spell again until the next dawn.

item.name: Witchlight Watch
item.reqAttune: by a mister witch or his handpicked successor
entries: This ornate pocket watch is fastened to the end of a gold chain. It glows with a faint golden light when opened, and it makes a soft ticking noise that can be heard only by the creature holding it. The face of the watch shows a miniature painting of the Witchlight Carnival ringed by a tiny henge, orbited at night by a mote of light small enough to slip through the eye of a needle. This light causes the henge to cast shadows, and these shadows allow the watch's owner to track the passage of time.

entries.name: Carnival Setup and Takedown
entries: The creature attuned to the watch can use an action to initiate the packing up or the unpacking of the Witchlight Carnival, provided the creature and the carnival are on the same plane of existence. In the span of 1 hour, all objects that are elements of the carnival are magically whisked about until everything is packed up and ready for travel, or unpacked and assembled. The watch has no effect on creatures, which can move about freely and safely while the carnival is being set up or taken down. Once the process of packing up or unpacking the carnival begins, it can't be stopped until the task is complete. When the watch is used to pack up or unpack the carnival, this property cannot be used again until 8 hours have elapsed.

entries.name: Additional Properties
entries: The pocket watch has the following additional properties:

items: While carrying the watch, the creature attuned to it can cast the {@spell fire bolt}, {@spell invisibility}, or {@spell message} spell as an action, requiring no spell components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability. After the watch's {@spell invisibility} spell is cast, roll a {@dice d8}; on a roll of 3 or 8, the watch can't be used to cast this spell again until the next dawn.
The creature attuned to the watch gains 30 pounds. This extra weight vanishes when the attunement ends.
The creature attuned to the watch must eat and drink eight times the normal amount each day.

item.name: Scatterleaf Tea
entries: As an action, a creature can scatter these tea leaves on the ground in a 5-foot-radius circle, duplicating the effect of a {@spell protection from evil and good} spell that lasts for 10 minutes. To gain the spell's protection, a creature must stand in the circle of tea leaves. In addition, a cup of hot, delicious tea magically appears in the protected creature's hands. A pouch contains enough leaves for one use.

table.name: Mood Rises
rows: Bright flowers you swore weren't there a second ago have blossomed underfoot, as a distant bird begins to sing sweetly, cutting through the babbling of the crowd.
The clouds ahead part and beautiful beams of moonlight that seem impossibly solid begin to bask the carnival grounds in dancing, ethereal light.

The distant music of the calliope that permeates the carnival swells to a grand crescendo, and you see several carnival goers are unconsciously smiling and nodding along and a group of children break out into dance.
A Tiefling on stilts breaths out a colossal burst of rainbow flame for a cheering crowd. The flames turn into a shower of butterflies that flitter into the audience, and the tiefling bows.

A group of Pixies flies through the air, trailing a stream of rainbow pixie dust, causing a group of children to rise into the air after them. Giggling, they begin a chase through the sky until the dust wears off and gently lowers the children back to the ground.

A cluster of brightly coloured mushrooms nearby begin to flicker and glow with rainbow light, as brightly coloured spores drift into the air and begin to pop like tiny fireworks, to the delight of a small group of Pixies nearby.

A Giant Dragonfly whizzes overhead and does a somersault in mid air as carnival goers cheer the rider on. Halfway through a barrel roll, they drop a handful of candy for the children below to scramble for, before flying off.

Three children with painted faces; a dragon, a lion, and a sheep; are playing at being a Chimera, chased by another child dressed as a knight, as carnival goers cheer them on. Eventually, the knight is victorious, and all three Chimera children play out a dramatic death as their parents laugh.

table.name: Mood Lowers
rows: As clouds pass across the moonlit sky, the colours of the carnival seem to fade. Flying banners and glowing lanterns are dimmer and greyer than they were a moment before.
The distant music of the calliope that permeates the carnival seems to take on a somber tone as it changes suddenly to a minor key, almost like a funeral dirge.
Clouds gather above, blocking out the light of the moon and stars, and a cold rain begins to fall. Carnival goers around you run for cover under the awnings and shiver.

The constant traffic of people and animals has turned the grass underfoot into sticky black mud. A faint odor begins to rise from the carnival grounds, of muck and manure, undercutting the scent of flowers and popcorn.

A running Halfling child trips over a root and spills her candy and popcorn all over the ground. She begins to cry, nursing a hurt knee, calling out for her parents: but they are nowhere to be found, as a Witchlight Hand escorts her to lost property.
The noise of the carnival seems muted, and the crowds seem thin. Small clusters of carnival goers drift quietly from stand to stand, but most of the attractions appear unusually dark and quiet.
A cluster of giant bubbles drifting overhead pop suddenly and drizzle everyone around you with a shower of cold, slimy liquid.

A little Halfling girl dressed as a Unicorn is in tears as she searches fruitlessly for her broken horn. Eventually, after searching through the mud unsuccessfully, her entire outfit is ruined and she gives up.

table.name: Carnival Scenes
rows: Two girls in face paint (a lion and a hart) squabble over a painted wooden crown that their mother won at a stall.
A satyr with red-and-white-striped horns plays the pipes while leading a procession of dancing rodents.
An elf stilt-walker tosses colorful sugary treats down to children who pass by.
A painted sign of an elf wearing a jester's hat springs to life and exclaims, "We hope you're having a delightful evening!"
A giant dragonfly swoops overhead, and its rider spills a drink over a group of Witchlight hands.
With a puff of glitter, a man's head suddenly turns into the head of a braying donkey, to the giggling delight of a group of mischievous pixies.
Giant, singing flowers burst from the ground and serenade passersby.
A lively jig springs up, led by a troupe of gnomish clowns.

rows: A fight breaks out at one of the tables over what the  answer to a question is. (eg, "it's fire! Dragons breathe fire!" "not all dragons do you dung beetle!")
A young girl comes up to the team and asks if they know the answer to the question. If they give it, the girl goes back to her table of grown men and they all cheer for her.

A random player must make a wisdom saving throw to avoid someone's detect thoughts spell. DC 15 Perception check reveals the wood elf in at the Thunder Bums table is using a spell scroll. He has already got their answer to the current question. If the character fails the save, he gets the answers to all their questions already answered.
The barmaid drops a bunch of wine bottles. A bunch of spirits escape. One turns into a spectre, a dog who wants to retrieve a bone it buried in life.
An acquaintance from the carnival comes by and says hello. The characters can choose who.
A halfling comes up to the party and asks if they'll give the answer to the last question to him for 15 gold. His name is Hobel.
A dwarf with fiery red hair comes up and tries to pick a fight with a random player, accusing them of cheating.

A fly lands on a random character's shoulder... it seems to be looking at the character's answer sheet. A DC15 arcana check reveals that it is a familiar. A DC20 perception check reveals which table it came from.

A large half orc (Grom) buys a drink for one of the players. Roll 1d4 to decide which. It's a goblet of the bar's specialty wine. Drinker must make a DC 20 CON save. On a fail, roll 1d6 for what the effect is:
1. Causes the drinker to revert to a child for the rest of the game.
2. Causes the drinker to act snobby and arrogant for the rest of the round.
3. Causes the drinker to have an increased appetite and have temptations to roll in the mud. The occasional burp from the ale comes out as an oink instead.
4. Causes the drinker to feel like fighting, and gives them advantage on intimidation checks and proficiency in unarmed strikes.
5. Causes the drinker to feel a bit more flirty and confident and have advantage on any charisma rolls to woo.
6. Causes the drinker to feel very smart but shy, and to gives them advantages on all intelligence checks.

A half orc at another table stands up and yells WHAT DO YOU MEAN YOU'RE OUT OF ORCNOG?! He flips the table and storms out, grabbing a mug off the Thunder Bums' table.  They complain loudly and follow him outside, abandoning their game. Outside, a fight breaks out, and the half orc (Grom) wins.

{@b 2-Parter: Per the PHB, what happens when an unconscious PC rolls a 1 on their Death Saving Throw? And what happens when they roll a 20?}

{@footnote ANSWER|{@color 1 = they suffer two failed death saves
20 = they regain consciousness with 1 HP|33CC33}|Answer}
{@i Bonus: If a player rolls a nat 20 on a death save, does their character get to take their turn immediately, or do they wait until the next round?}
{@footnote Bonus Answer|{@color The death save happens at the start of their turn. They get to take their turn if they regain consciousness.|33CC33}|Bonus Answer}

{@b An ancient white dragon's movement stats read as follows: Speed: 40 ft., borrow 40 ft., fly 80 ft., swim 40 ft.  What is the longest distance the dragon can naturally cover on one turn (without benefitting from any extra magical affects, legendary actions, etc.)?}

{@footnote ANSWER|{@color 160 ft.|33CC33}
If they use their movement to fly 80 ft. and dash action to fly another 80 ft.|Answer}
{@i Bonus: If the dragon first moves 25 ft., then grapples a PC (successfully), then attempts to move while grappling, what is the longest distance the dragon can naturally cover on that turn?}

{@footnote Bonus Answer|{@color 25 ft.|33CC33}
No dash available anymore, grappling is half-speed, and always round down. (80 - 25) / 2 = 27.5, rounds down to 25.|Bonus Answer}

{@b A creature with 3 HP is hit with a melee attack for 5 damage.  Unfortunately, the player didn't want to kill the creature... they wanted to leave it alive to question it.  Assuming there are no extra affects or traits which alter the damage amount, which of the following is true?}

items: A. The creature is reduced to 0 HP and dies instantly, while the player can choose an adjacent target to deal the remaining 2 damage to.
B. The creature is reduced to -2 HP and dies instantly.
C. The creature is reduced to 0 HP and dies instantly.
D. On a successful hit, a player can always choose to apply as much or as little of the damage as they like.
E. The player can choose to deal a killing blow, or leave the monster unconscious but stable at 0 HP.
F. The DM must make a ruling: per the PHB, either the creature dies instantly, or the attack action is forfeit, dealing no damage.

entries: {@footnote ANSWER|{@color E|33CC33}|Answer}
{@i Bonus: When can the player make the decision to leave the creature alive?}
{@footnote Bonus Answer|{@color Per the PHB: "the instant the damage is dealt"|33CC33}|Bonus Answer}

{@b A PC sees 3 potions before him. He drinks the first, and learns that it grants him 3 Temporary Hit Points. He drinks the next one, which grants him 5 Temp HP. He excitedly drinks the last one, which grants him only 1 Temp HP.  Assuming he started with 0 Temp HP, how many Temporary Hit Points does the PC now have?}

{@footnote ANSWER|{@color 5 Temporary Hit Points|33CC33}
Temporary Hit points do not stack, so you just take the highest value granted.|Answer}

{@i Bonus: Let's say the PC had a max HP of 51 but had already taken 17 points of damage before drinking any of the Temp HP potions. Let's also say the potions are magically trapped... Between drinking potion #1 and #2, the PC is subjected to an affect that reduces his Maximum HP by half. Then, between drinking potions #2 and #3, the PC takes 7 pts of psychic damage.  What would his final HP stats be?}
{@footnote Bonus Answer|{@color HP: 23 / Temp HP: 1|33CC33}|Bonus Answer}

{@b (This one has a tricky answer) A creature with a STR score of 10 and speed of 35 ft. but no stat for swimming speed or climbing speed stands 5 ft. away from a 15-ft-wide moat. The creature wants to cross the moat and then immediately climb straight up a 20-foot castle wall. Applying only common PHB movement options and action economy (assuming no extra effects or abilities are at play that can modify their mobility), at most, how far up the wall can the creature make it on their turn?}

{@footnote ANSWER|{@color All the way to top! (20 ft. up), as long as the creature first performs a standing jump into the moat, then swims the remainder, then takes the dash action while climbing.|33CC33}
Swimming and climbing are both half-speed, so after running up 5 ft., it would normally take 30 ft. of movement to swim the moat, however a standing long jump allows the creature to clear 5 ft. (half its strength score in feet) in the air, costing only 5 ft. of its movement. Swimming the remainder would cost 20 ft. of movement, leaving the creature 5 ft. of movement left to climb just 2½ ft. up the wall. Then, if the creature takes the dash action, it can cover another 17½ ft. of climbing--just enough to reach the top!|Answer}
{@i Bonus: Let's say the creature backed up 5ft, then ran 10 ft. toward the moat so it could perform a long jump.  How would this affect their total movement?}

{@footnote Bonus Answer|They would only make it {@color 17½ ft. up the wall|33CC33}, considering that backing away and then running up would use 15 ft. of movement, and the jump would clear 10 ft. (strength score), after swimming the remainder and dashing while climbing, they'd run out of movement 17½ feet up.|Bonus Answer}

entries: {@b Point out as many rules errors in the following paragraph as possible (hypothetical errors accepted, when relevant... ex: "if X {@i were} true, then Y would also be wrong", etc.):}

{@b A level 5 Rogue is facing a goblin and a wolf which is currently prone. After being attacked by the goblin, on the Rogue's turn, she uses her reaction to roll a DEX save against the goblin's scimitar attack, then use her first action to drop her dagger in order to grasp her rapier with two hands, increasing the damage die.}

{@b Then for her second action, she moves away from the goblin and toward the wolf, a total of 15 ft. of movement, and then she attacks. On her d20, the player rolls a 17 for her attack, and the DM says "Nice!  17 plus your +3 DEX ability modifier makes that a 20, which totally beats the wolf's DC. Hey, in fact that's a 20, so it's a critical hit!"}

{@b The player then rolls for damage, and she and the DM add it up, the DM announcing the details: "Okay, for your 1d10 versatile weapon damage you rolled 9, and then your proficiency bonus gives you a +2 modifier.  So that's 11, tripled for the crit becomes 33. Are you also going to use your Sneak Attack?  Ok great, so for your 3d6 sneak attack damage, you rolled 19... so that all comes out to a total of... 52 slashing damage.  Unbelievable! How do you wanna do it?!"}

{@footnote ANSWER|Answer: 20 Possible Errors (at least that I know of)...

1. Rolling a DEX Save is not a reaction, and it's usually not part of your turn either. It's only ever done in response to some other trigger.

2. A goblin's scimitar attack does not require a DEX save. Also, resolving whether the goblin hit or not would have already happened before the Rogue's turn.

2. You only get one action per turn. Some classes may get two attacks per action, but actually rogues don't!

3. Dropping something in your hands (like a dagger) is not an action. It's considered a "free object interaction".

4. Rapiers are not versatile, meaning that grasping them with two hands does nothing to increase the damage.

5. Moving is part of the Rogue's "movement", not technically part of her action, as the text described it.

6. The goblin gets an attack of opportunity if the Rogue moves 15 ft. If the goblin just attacked her with a scimitar, the Rogue is certainly within its reach, and moving 15 ft in any direction means she's leaving its reach.

7. She should have rolled with advantage. The wolf was prone and she was making a meleé attack. In fact, having advantage is the only reason Sneak Attack applies here. Without advantage, she shouldn't have presumed that she could use Sneak Attack in the first place. Hypothetically.

8. The DM forgot to add the Rogue's proficiency bonus to the attack roll. The attack roll modifiers on a non-crit include ability modifier and proficiency.

9. The DM said the attack roll beat the monster's "DC"... should have said "AC" (meaning "armor class").

10. The DM announced that it was a "critical hit", which it isn't. Only a rolled natural 20 is a crit (unless you have some additional class feature like the "Improved Critical" feature of a Champion archetype fighter).

11. Rapiers do 1d8 damage, not 1d12. Again, a rapier is not a "versatile" weapon, so its damage roll remains 1d8, even when wielded with two hands.

13. Proficiency bonus is not added to weapon damage. It is added to attack rolls, but not damage rolls.

14. The proficiency bonus for a Level 5 character would be +3. Assuming she's a 5th level character, proficiency should not be +2, as the DM stated.

15. Ability modifier should have been added to the weapon damage (e.g. +3 DEX modifier). Since a rapier is a "finesse" weapon, either the DEX or STR ability can be used, so unless the player had a +0 to both DEX and STR (which they didn't, according to what the DM said earlier in the paragraph), they forgot to add this.

16. Hypothetically, damage on a critical hit is doubled, not tripled. Had this been a real crit, they seemingly would have messed that up too.

17. Hypothetically, damage modifiers are not multiplied on a crit. Damage modifiers are added only after the attack damage is doubled.

18. Hypothetically, the 3d6 Sneak Attack damage mathematically couldn't have been above 18. The DM said it was. Not really a RULE gaff, but still an obvious mathematical error.

19. Hypothetically, Sneak Attack damage is doubled on a crit. To be clear, this attack was not a critical hit, but if it had been, the Sneak Attack dice, which are part of the attack damage, should have been double along with the weapon damage.

20. A rapier does piercing damage, not slashing damage.

21. Rogues can't be girls (yeah just kidding)|Answer} (hold shift and hover to lock pop-up in place)

entries.title: The arrival of the Witchlight Carnival is a highly anticipated event

entries.name: Adventure Summary
entries: The goal of this side quest is to present your characters with a fun distraction from their possibly violent campaigning. The Witchlight Carnival is in town, and your characters have a day (or two) to kill, so why not buy a ticket and play some carnival games? The reward for completing enough of the objectives throughout the carnival is a chance for the adventurers to visit a fantastical magic shop, stocked with all manner of spell scrolls and magic items that may help the adventurers on their quests.

To enter the {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}, the characters must first visit the carnival, which travels across the Material Plane and appears on the characters' world once every eight years. The carnival owners are a pair of shadar-kai (elves native to the Shadowfell) named {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC}, who can help or hinder the characters' efforts to reach {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}.

entries.name: Eight and Three
entries: As you run {@i The Witchlight Carnival}, look for ways to bring the numbers eight and three to the fore.

The number eight is symbolically important, as this adventure plays with the themes of time and nostalgia. The numeral 8 resembles an hourglass, which measures the passage of time, and looks like the symbol for infinity (∞) turned on its side. Hidden within the numeral 8 itself is the numeral 3. In the D&D multiverse, there exists the Rule of Three, which states that events of cosmic consequence often manifest in threes. Time, for instance, has a past, present, and future.
Hidden within the adventure are numerous other mentions of the numbers eight and three. Can you find them all?

entries.name: Beginning the Adventure
entries: How the characters become embroiled in the adventure depends on what type of hook you choose to use to pull them into it. Choose either the "Old Man's Quest" adventure hook detailed below, or a custom plot hook. It can be as simple as "the carnival is in town, and everyone in the village is excited to attend... and you've got some time to kill before the next leg of your adventure!"

entries.name: Old Man's Quest
entries: In this preamble, an aging treasure hunter named Madryck Roslof tells the characters about a fantastical magic shop called {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}, which exists only in a pocket dimension and can only be reached by finding and using a portal in the carnival. Madryck says that he stumbled upon it years ago and bartered for a magic item which he's now lost. He impores the characters to journey to this pocket dimension and try to buy back some of what he barted away: years of his now dwindling life.

If you like, you can replace Madryck Roslof with a different NPC who better suits your campaign, such as Reidoth, the druid. Whether Madryck or someone else gives the quest, the characters must enter the carnival and charm their way into the good graces of the carnival owners, {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} to be invited to use the portal, or investigate and unravel clues in order to discover the secret portal themselves.

entries.name: Setting the Stage
entries: To kick off the adventure, read the following boxed text to your players:

You have been summoned to the abode of a renounced treasure hunter named Madryck Roslof. His adventuring days are behind him, and he looks quite old and frail. Nevertheless, he is delighted, or maybe relieved to make your acquaintance. A servant enters the room with a cup of tea for the old man.
Madryck: "Ah, thank you, Orsen." [hacking cough]
Orsen: "Of course my old friend." He turns to face you. "May I get you anything? Tea? Pamplemousse La Croix?"

Osren only has Blackgrass Tea and a single La Croix on hand: Lime (no pamplemousse).  Madryck, once wealthy from all his treasure hunting, is now just scraping by, and has reduced Orsen's salary to the point that the servant had to look for work elsewhere. And, having already given his two-week notice, this is actually his last day.

"I'll try get right to the point.  I've acquired many treasures during my lengthy adventuring career," says Madryck. "but none as marvelous as the one I accquired from a legendary magic merchant. His magic shop, whose name I shall not utter, is not easily found, and his wares do not come cheap.  For I was only able to acquire my prize by bartering for it. The item was tarnished brass framed spectacle, unassuming in appearance, but it granted the wearer the ability to find what they were looking for, be it lost items, clues, or even hidden treasures. The asking price was well beyond my means, so I struck a deal: in exchange for this spectacle, I traded 38 years of my life. At the budding young age of 20, it seemed like a fair deal at the time. But now look at me. Nearing death. I look and feel all of 90, when I'm actually in my 50's. I gambled away my twilight years for a parlor trick trinket that I've now... [sigh]... lost.  Yes, it's true.  It was a magic item that literally finds other items, making it the only object in my posession that I could {@i possibly lose}... Oh the terrible irony.  And now I am left with such regret over my foolish trade, I cannot stand it." [Hacking cough]

Madryck looks up at you with aged, sagging eyes. "Please. I implore you to return to the magic shop and try to buy back some of my years. Take this and try to sell it to the shop keeper in exchange for as many years of my life as he'll trade back. It's not much but since losing my spectacle, I've slowly had to sell off my treasures, and this ring is now all I have to trade."

Madryck extends a shaky arm and opens his hand to reveal a small wooden ring. "It is imbued with the magical gift of animal kinship. The wearer can speak with birds and beasts, and gains influence over them when needed." He forces a smile, "In the right hands it really could be quite powerful!" he says enthusiastically, doing his best to promote the ring's worth. "Please convince the shop keep of its considerable value."

"Know this: The merchant's shop is not simple to find. It exists in a pocket dimension between planes, and can only be accessed one way: Every eight years, our world is visited by a traveling extravaganza called the Witchlight Carnival, and hidden somewhere in the carnival is a doorway to the magic shop. The exact location of this portal changes constantly, but rest assured that {@i someone} always knows where it is.  The Carnival has recently returned to this world and is camped closeby, just outside of Phandalin. I'm asking you now because the carnival might pack up and leave at any time, and it contains your only route to the dimensional crossing where you'll find the magic shop, the shop whose terrible name I fear to utter aloud!"
"Seek out the portal. Take my ring to the merchant. Buy me back some of my precious years."

The players may want to know more about the portal and how to find it—who should they ask about its location? What does it look like? Is it dangerous to pass through?  Here's what Madryck knows and is willing to share:

items: {@b What does the portal look like?} The portal is not going to be visible to just anyone. Only the Witchligh Monarch can see the portal. If none of the heros are crowned the Witchlight Monarch, they'll have to devise some other means of learning its location.
{@b Is it dangerous?} Entering the portal is not dangerous. Though, time flows differently in the pocket dimension.
{@b Who should they talk to?} Currying the favor of the carnival owners is adviseable, though it's not a guaranteed that even they know of the portal's existance or location.

{@b What exactly does the ring do? / What is it called?} "I call this Madryck's Ring!" he says, and starts to chuckle, which turns into a hacking cough. The ring bestows the effects of the {@spell Speak With Animals} spell on the wearer, and grants advantage on {@skill Animal Handling} checks, as well as Charisma checks made to influence beasts.
{@b How does "buying back years" work? How do they know if it's successful?} If his theory is right, the shop keeper's word is all they need. That's all it took last time, at least.
{@b What's the shop keeper's name?} He has gone by many names. There are those who call him Garfield the Deals Warlock
{@b What's the name of this magic shop?} A DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check convinces Madryck to reluctantly whisper the name: "{@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}".

entries.name: To the Carnival
entries: Characters who accept Madryck's quest can make the uneventful trek to the carnival, which is located not too far from a settlement of your choosing. The characters arrive shortly before twilight. When they arrive, lay out the poster map of the carnival for the players to see.

data.name: Witchlight Carnival
entries: The Witchlight Carnival is a fairground of kaleidoscopic tents and wagons crewed by wondrous beings, including many denizens of the Feywild. This is no ordinary carnival; it uses magic to travel from world to world across the Material Plane, visiting each world once every eight years and setting up business on the outskirts of populated areas. The carnival spends a few days at each location, then packs up and moves to another location on the same world until the decision is made to leave that world and visit the next. The carnival includes a dimensional crossing, allowing travel to the magic shop known as {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}.
The characters are free to explore the carnival as they please, so it can play out differently each time you run it.

entries.title: The Witchlight Carnival visits a world once every eight years, bringing wonder and whimsy to the Material Plane

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: Before running the Witchlight Carnival, follow the steps below to help make the experience smoother:

items: Familiarize yourself with the layout of the Witchlight Carnival. The map that appears in this chapter is a smaller version of the carnival poster map.
Read the chapter and familiarize yourself with the carnival's attractions. The characters can go anywhere at any time, so you need to be prepared for anything.
Prepare the tracking devices described in "Carnival Map." You'll need a {@dice d8} to track the passage of time and another token to track the carnival's mood on the poster map.

entries.name: Carnival Map
entries: On the poster map of the carnival, use a miniature figure or some other token to mark where each character is located at any given time. If the characters split up, the tokens will make it easier to keep track of everyone.
The poster map has places to track two crucial elements: the passage of time and the carnival's mood.

entries.name: Tracking Time
entries: The Witchlight Carnival opens at dusk and runs for eight hours, ending just before dawn. When the characters enter the carnival, place a {@dice d8} at the start of the track in the upper left corner of the poster map with the "1" facing up. Move the die to the next space at the end of each in-game hour, and turn the die so that its uppermost face shows the hour that is now beginning. Don't worry about managing things down to the minute. If the players (and their characters) seem to be having fun, you can slow down the passage of time to give them time to enjoy the carnival's attractions. If the game starts to lag or if the characters spend a lot of time engaged in the same activity, advance the die to the next hour.
Three events take place every night at a particular hour:

items.name: Hour 1:
items.entry: {@area Welcome Gifts|0ec|x}. Small gifts are handed out to lucky guests.

items.name: Hour 4:
items.entry: {@area Big Top Extravaganza|0f0|x}. A midnight show gives the characters the chance to dazzle spectators and impress the carnival's ringmaster.

items.name: Hour 8:
items.entry: {@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x}. The carnival's climactic event gives the characters a chance to meet the carnival's mysterious owners.

entries: Each event is detailed in the "{@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x}" section toward the end of the chapter.

entries.name: Tracking Mood
entries: The characters' actions in the Witchlight Carnival can affect the overall mood at the carnival. When the characters arrive at the carnival, place a token in the starting space of the track in the lower right corner of the poster map. This token moves right or left along the track as the carnival's atmosphere changes for better or worse.

The text informs you when to raise or lower the mood. When the token is to the right of the starting space, spirits are high: colors appear more vibrant, flowers bloom around the fairgrounds, and shooting stars sweep across the clear night sky (roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table}). When the token is to the left of the starting space, the mood becomes darker: the calliope music plays discordantly, the staff is tense, and stormy weather looms in the sky above the carnival. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

The carnival's mood is used to trigger an important meeting between the characters and the carnival owners. If the mood reaches either of the end spaces on the track, the carnival's owners invite the characters to speak with them in their wagon (see "{@area Through the Looking Glass|0f8|x}" toward the end of the chapter). Characters who attend the Big Top Extravaganza can also receive an invitation to meet with the owners, even if the carnival's mood isn't in an extreme state.

entries.name: Carnival Owners
entries: The owners of the Witchlight Carnival are a pair of shadar-kai (elves native to the Shadowfell) named {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC}. Witch is matter-of-fact and devoid of pretense, while Light is flamboyant and coy.

How Witch and Light came to possess the carnival is a story worth telling. Under different names, they owned another carnival that prowled the edges of the Shadowfell. The two carnivals crossed paths many years ago, and after much wine was consumed, the owners could not agree on which carnival was the better of the two, so they decided it would be great fun to swap ownership. Isolde, the eladrin who ran the fey-themed carnival, traded places with the two shadar-kai who ran the shadow-themed carnival. This arrangement would last until the two carnivals met again, which has not yet happened.

After trading their sinister carnival for a more lighthearted one, the two shadar-kai took the names Witch and Light. Gradually, these morose, emotionally stunted shadar-kai transformed into fun-loving free spirits who secretly dread the day when the two carnivals cross paths again. They have no desire to return to their gloomy old carnival, which is described in more detail in {@book Van Richten's Guide to Ravenloft|VRGR}.

The shadar-kai are aware that the Hourglass Coven has usurped Zybilna's domain in the Feywild. They don't know how the coven accomplished this coup, but Witch and Light would like nothing more than to see the hags defeated and Zybilna returned to power. But they dare not play a part in making that dream a reality. If the coven caught a whiff of dissent from Witch and Light, the hags would punish the shadar-kai for their impudence (see the "Witch and Light's Hourglass Pact" sidebar). Witch and Light do what they can to appease the hags while secretly rooting for Zybilna's return. They know Zybilna's true identity but dare not reveal it.

entries.name: Mister Witch
entries: Witch, who used to go by the name Naeryx Krumple, spent his youth as a homeless orphan, eking out a meager and dreary existence on the fog-shrouded streets of Gloomwrought, a city in the Shadowfell. He earned a few coppers selling broadsheets as a young boy, then later swept floors until an old clock tower keeper took him on as a helper. The tower's clock was in such poor condition that it would break down often. Naeryx helped with the repairs and found that the work gave him a sliver of joy. When the old keeper died years later, Naeryx replaced him.

The wealthy family that owned the clock tower didn't pay Naeryx a lot of money for his work, but they occasionally had him over for dinner. He owned one fine suit that he wore on such occasions, and though he didn't care for the family's matriarch or patriarch, he enjoyed the company of their eldest son, Urmius Umbrage—a brooding shadar-kai ne'er-do-well with a cruel sense of humor. Naeryx and Urmius were close in age and got along well in all respects. Years later, without informing the rest of his family, Urmius bought a run-down carnival and persuaded Naeryx to help him operate it. Naeryx and Urmius—now calling themselves {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC}—have been partners and collaborators ever since.

entries.name: Mister Witch's Description
entries: {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} looks like a distinguished gentleman, for he is always dressed in fine attire. His favorite accoutrements are a top hat and a cane, and he is never without his {@item Witchlight watch|TWC}, which was gifted to him by the carnival's previous owner. This unique magic item is described below.

entries.name: Mister Light
entries: Light, formerly known as Urmius Umbrage, belonged to a filthy rich shadar-kai family that haunted a crumbling mansion in Gloomwrought. Although he wanted for nothing as a child, Urmius found himself surrounded by family members, caretakers, and teachers who were uniformly cold, callous, and mean-spirited. He grew tired of being seen as nothing more than the inheritor of the Umbrage estate and legacy, and he did everything in his power to make life miserable for everyone around him, especially his parents. He seemed bereft of ambition and spent much of his time playing in his room. He collected costumes and liked nothing more than to parade around Umbrage Mansion in strange garments and outlandish makeup.

Urmius first met Naeryx Krumple at a family dinner and didn't think much of the clock tower keeper at first. But Urmius found himself taken aback by Naeryx's ability to find even a small amount of joy in his work. He was eager to get to know Naeryx better, though it took a while for Naeryx to trust him. After getting his hands on some money, Urmius bought a sad little carnival that was camped on the outskirts of Gloomwrought and asked Naeryx to help him run it. For Urmius, the carnival was a chance to emerge from under his family's shadow and become the master of his own fate, but it also meant forsaking his inheritance in order to embrace the unconventional lifestyle, fashions, and friendships he desired.

entries.name: Mister Light's Description
entries: {@creature Mister Light|TWC} has a slender frame. He is always dressed in some sort of costume and is rarely seen in public without makeup. He carries around a fancy weather vane given to him by the carnival's previous owner. He twirls it and waves it around like a fool's scepter, but its power is far greater than he lets on. With this magic vane, he can affect the mood of everyone in the Witchlight Carnival.

entries.name: Witchlight Hands
entries: {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight Hands} are the backbone of the Witchlight Carnival, a motley collection of individuals who operate many of the booths, make repairs, feed and exercise the animals, keep an eye out for thieves and other miscreants, and perform other miscellaneous tasks as {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} dictates. A few also work part-time as performers and attractions. Although they travel to many worlds throughout the Material Plane, Witchlight hands rarely leave the carnival grounds. The carnival is the only world they know and care about.

The carnival employs 124 Witchlight hands in total. All hands enter into an agreement when they join the carnival: they must never harm another staff member, and they can't leave the carnival for more than a day at a time. (A longer absence is equivalent to resignation, in {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}'s estimation.) On-duty staff members are required to wear fake butterfly wings strapped to their backs. {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} also furnish them with small amounts of {@item pixie dust|TWC}.

Witchlight hands are paid only a small fraction of the carnival's profits, but it's enough to keep them fed, clothed, and cared for. Some hands work longer hours or do extra chores to pay off debts and loans.

Most Witchlight hands are taught how to perform minor magic tricks, which they use to amuse themselves as well as entertain the masses. (Characters who have the Witchlight hand background don't learn magic as part of their upbringing, but they can choose to account for this by selecting a spellcasting class.)

entries.name: Carnival Overview
entries: Use the following boxed text to describe the carnival to new arrivals:

The first stars of night twinkle above the apricot sunset. Giant dragonflies whir overhead, trailing streamers, and a low mist curls over the ground. Through a floral archway, you glimpse wondrous and vibrant creatures—elf stilt walkers, dancing faeries, and painted performers. Everywhere there is laughter, pixie dust, bubbles, and the wistful tune of a whistling calliope.

The Witchlight Carnival travels as a convoy of wagons, each one pulled by horses or foxes depending on its size. When they need to soar between worlds, the wagons and their draft animals sprout butterfly wings and take to the starry sky. On land, the carnival's attractions unfold magically from the wagons, controlled by {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}'s {@item Witchlight watch|TWC}.

When the carnival arrives at a new destination, a {@creature treant sapling|TWC} named Northwind uses its Animate Trees ability to gently relocate trees that are in the way of the unfolded wagons. A great length of blue ribbon transforms into a lazy, sparkling river, encircling the site. The river is 20 feet wide and 10 feet deep at its center.

entries.name: Carnival Etiquette
entries: There's no handbook for how guests of the Witchlight Carnival are expected to behave; certain actions are tolerated, while others cause offense. Politeness goes a long way: paying attention when spoken to, laughing at jokes, and joining in with games and singing. Every so often, you can raise the carnival's mood by 1 step (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}" earlier in the chapter, and roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table}) if the party is consistently polite to carnival staff and fellow attendees.

Conversely, acts such as interrupting someone, being rude, or grumpily refusing to dance are unfavorable. Lower the carnival's mood by 1 step if the characters actively offend anyone they meet. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

entries.name: Theft and Violence
entries: Characters who are caught stealing or fighting are asked to leave the carnival; in this case, the carnival's mood lowers by 1 step (roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table}) as {@dice 1d6} {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hands} (chaotic good; see the stat block earlier in the chapter) escort the troublemakers to the gates.

entries.name: Bringing the Carnival to Life
entries: Roll on the {@table Carnival Scenes|TWC} table to bring the carnival to life as the players explore.

entries.name: Wandering Outsiders
entries: Several meddling outsiders can be encountered at various times throughout the evening.

entries.name: Kester
entries: Kester is a kenku arcane trickster whose employer is a rival carnival owner. He is committed to causing trouble to hurt business. Kester uses {@spell disguise self} to assume whatever form best enables him to mingle in crowds.
Characters can encounter Kester in more than one location; if they corner him, he can be intimidated or bribed into leaving.

entries.name: Thieves of the Coven
entries: Each member of the Hourglass Coven employs a thief that visits the carnival to steal from ticketless victims. These thieves enter and exit through the Hall of Illusions, using it as a gateway to their mistresses' splinter-realms of Hither, Thither, and Yon. The carnival staff has been instructed by {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} to ignore them.

These thieves possess a preternatural awareness of who is a carnival worker and who is a ticket-carrying visitor. Every night of the carnival, they haunt the dark spaces between wagons and attractions, scanning the crowds for ticketless interlopers. Characters who have tickets or who work at the carnival are not targets for these thieves. Some characters might catch glimpses of these spooky figures as reflections in mirrors, shadows in doorways, or out-of-place figures standing motionless in the moving crowd. Use these thieves as you please to add an undercurrent of dread or mystery to the carnival's frivolities.

entries.name: Carnival Events
entries: This section describes special events that occur during the characters' visit to the carnival.

entries.name: Catching Kester
entries: {@creature Kester the Kenku|TWC|Kester} (see the accompanying stat block) snoops around the carnival under the cover of a {@spell disguise self} spell, looking to cause trouble. The kenku has stolen the voice of a human mime named Candlefoot (see "{@area Hall of Illusions|0a6|x}" earlier in the chapter). While this prize remains in his possession, Kester can speak clearly in Candlefoot's soft, silky voice.

If Kester has not already been caught, a character who spends 1 hour searching for the disguised kenku can, with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, see through his disguise while moving through crowds and paying close attention to suspicious-looking folks. If discovered, Kester tries to flee from the main thoroughfare, using tents and other carnival features to break line of sight to her. He's willing to cautiously parley with characters who claim they are investigating the carnival for their own reasons.

entries.name: Talking with Kester
entries: If the characters corner him, Kester tells his story in the voice he stole from Candlefoot:

items: Kester was hired by a rival carnival, The Harlem and Haley Brother's Circus. The circus usually does decent business, but every 8 years when the Witchlight Carnival comes to the Material Plane, they nearly go bankrupt.
He was hired with the objective of stirring up trouble, lowering the mood of the carnival, and generally hurting business. Their loss is Harlem and Haley's gain.

He's being paid handsomely to wreak havoc. A DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check can convince Kester to tell them his price: 500 gp. With a roll of 20 or higher, Kester will consider an offer to outbid his employers (double or more) in order to buy him out.
A DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check can convince Kester to leave the carnival and never return.

entries: If questioned about the theft of Candlefoot's voice, Kester produces a corn husk doll with a thorny stem tied around its neck. The doll represents Candlefoot, and untying the stem restores the mime's lost voice. Any character who succeeds on a DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Persuasion}) check can convince Kester to part with the doll.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters reunite Candlefoot with his voice, Candlefoot seeks out Palasha and proposes marriage to her. Reuniting the couple causes the carnival's mood to rise by 2 steps. Roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). From that point on, Palasha and Candlefoot treat the characters as trusted allies, which could prove useful during the crowning of the Witchlight Monarch, as they both have roles to play in the coronation.
{@note The following events occur at specific times throughout the evening.}

entries.name: Hour 1: Welcome Gifts
entries: Shortly after the carnival opens for business, read:

A twelve-foot-tall walking tree garlanded in golden ribbons marches down the thoroughfare. Emerald clouds swirl above the tree and rain down golden, spinning sycamore seeds. Fairgoers try to catch the seeds before they hit the ground. As the seeds gently fall, a chatty squirrel scampers along the boughs of the tree, handing dandelions to select passersby.

The tree is Northwind, a {@creature treant sapling|WBtW} (see its stat block earlier in the chapter), and the squirrel is its trusty companion, Red (see "{@area Dragonfly Rides|09a|x}" earlier in the chapter). As Northwind encourages onlookers to catch the falling seeds before they touch the ground, Red hands the characters one dandelion apiece and encourages each of them to make a wish and then blow the dandelion's seeds into the air.

entries.name: Sycamore Seeds
entries: A creature can attempt to catch a falling sycamore seed before it touches the ground, doing so with a successful DC 10 Dexterity check. Any creature that catches a seed before it touches the ground receives a gift, determined by rolling a {@dice d8} and consulting the Welcome Gifts table. A creature that receives one of these gifts can't gain another one for 24 hours.

entries.name: Dandelion Seeds
entries: A character can make a wish while blowing their dandelion's seeds into the air. The player should secretly write down their character's wish on a piece of paper; collect these notes and keep them somewhere safe.

entries.caption: Welcome Gifts
rows: The creature gains the following personality trait until dawn: "I am easily amused." Any conflicting character trait is suppressed in the meantime.
The creature gains a die, a {@dice d4}, which it can add to one ability check it makes before the next dawn.
The seed turns into a gold piece.
The creature gains a die, a {@dice d8}, which it can add to one ability check it makes before the next dawn.

entries.name: Hour 4: Big Top Extravaganza
entries: Spectators file into the Big Top and fill the rows of seats. If the characters join them, read:

The lights dim and a hush falls over the crowd. A second later, a spotlight illuminates a lithe, elven figure sitting in a silver hoop, suspended above the center ring by silk ropes. The elf wears a dazzling suit of diamond-pane mirrors and a pair of butterfly wings. His scepter is topped with a spinning vane.
"Welcome, one and all, to this evening's extravaganza! I am {@creature Mister Light|TWC}. Prepare to be delighted!"
The extravaganza involves several of the carnival's star performers and attractions, with {@creature Mister Light|TWC} serving as ringmaster. Over the course of an hour, the following events occur:

Burly the bugbear performs feats of strength, Palasha the mermaid serenades the audience from a clamshell bathing pool, Candlefoot the mime plays silent games with audience members, and faerie dragons with bright streamers tied to their tails perform dazzling acts of synchronized flying as a troupe of acrobats, clowns, and fire-breathers parade about. If the characters attempt to disrupt the show, {@creature Mister Light|TWC} deflects their interruptions with banter and maintains a jovial demeanor. Persistent heckling lowers the carnival's mood by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

entries.name: Burly the Bugbear's Feats of Strength

entries: Walking out of a cloud of smoke and light, a massive, hairy Bugbear, wearing dungarees and a pumpkin helmet, steps out onto the stage, flexing his impressive muscles. He carries an enormous metal pole, easily at least twenty feet long, and it glints under the lights.

{@creature bugbear|Burly the Bugbear} will offer for volunteers from the crowd to hang off each end of the pole, and he will lift them: first one on each end, then two, then three, pausing for applause from the audience in between each feat of strength. Burly is capable of lifting 900lbs without needing to do any kind of ability check: the average human weighs approximately 150lbs. If it seems likely that the weight of the volunteers modifier, with the DC being the Con score of the heaviest volunteer on the pole.

After these feats of strength, two {@creature Goblin} stage hands dressed as jesters wheel out a large tub of water and a long rope: Burly will challenge anyone in the audience to a tug of war, and will even welcome two opponents at once!

The tug of war takes the form of a contested {@skill Athetics} check (Burly has a +6 bonus). If two characters are on one end of the rope, one can use the Help action on the other to give them Advantage on the roll. The loser will get pulled into the water with a dramatic splash.

Defeating Burly earns raucous applause from the crowd, as the Bugbear will lift the contestants above his head to celebrate their victory. Even if a character loses, Burly will help them out of the pool and encourage the audience to applaud their effort.

entries.name: Palasha's Serenade

entries: A giant clamshell is wheeled out, and the lights go down. The lid slowly begins to open in complete silence, until an unearthly, beautiful voice begins to undulate from within: suddenly the lights come up and reveal Palasha the Mermaid, who sings in Aquan, a language that sounds like it's being sung underwater even though you're sitting on dry land. Bubbles of water begin to ripple through the air around her, causing the lights of the tent to shimmer and ripple.

As she sings, {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hands} move through the audience handing out sea creature kites that seem to swim through the air as you hold their string. They will gesture to the stage and encourage the party to join the crowd of children who are excitedly making an underwater scene with their animated kite puppets.

rows: Kite
Dolphin
Jellyfish
Shark
Stingray
Seahorse
Sea Serpent
Octopus
Mermaid

entries: Have each character make a DC 14 {@skill Performance} check, as they describe how they play with their kite during the song.

After the performance finishes, Palasha will gesture to the puppeteers for their own round of applause. Anyone who passed the Performance check recieves a fish scale with one use of the Shape Water cantrip from a {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight Hand} as they collect the kites back up.

entries.name: Candlefoot's Games

entries: A pale, lanky mime dressed in black and white moves through the crowd, followed by the sounds of laughter and delight.

Candlefoot the mime will perform tricks of sleight of hand with the audience. His favorite act is to seemingly slide a copper piece into one ear, ask the audience member to tap their head, and then he'll pull the coin out of the other. He will do this with multiple audience members, until he finds a party member.

This time, he puts a copper in, but pulls out a gold. Expressing shock, he polishes it, he bites it, and he looks closely in the character's ear. He tentatively puts another copper in, and lo and behold, another gold comes out. He excitedly pulls out all the copper pieces he has in his pockets and appears to pour them all into the character's head before waiting eagerly at the other side for his payout... which comes as only one single copper piece.
Dejected, he inspects the players ear, taps on their head and listens, then shrugs sadly, turns out his pockets, and sulks sadly away, as the audience sighs "Aaaaaaw".

He'll hold out his hand for donations and cheer up more and more with every gift. Any character who gives Candlefoot a gold piece receives a gift of thanks with a sly wink: a sachet of {@item pixie dust|TWC}.

entries.name: Open Mic
entries: Near the end of the show, {@creature Mister Light|TWC} asks if any guests would like to perform their own acts for the crowd. Any character who accepts the offer can woo spectators with a DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check, raising the carnival's mood by 1 step on a success (roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table}). If multiple characters choose to perform together, make it a group check instead, but raise the carnival's mood by 2 steps if the group check succeeds (roll once on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table}). A character can improve the carnival's mood only once during this extravaganza.

At the end of the show, Burly invites any characters who took to the stage and impressed the crowd to meet with {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} (see "{@area Through the Looking Glass|0f8|x}" earlier in the chapter).

entries.name: Extravaganza Finale

entries: As the show comes to close, a dozen Faerie Dragons with bright streamers tied to their tails perform dazzling acts of synchronized flying as a troupe of acrobats, clowns, and firebreathers parade about. The slender, colourful {@creature Mister Light|TWC|Mr. Light} brandishes his scepter high above his head and invites anyone from the audience on stage to perform for the crowd. As he does, several giggling children run up immediately and start dancing and falling over.
If {@creature Kester the Kenku|TWC|Kester} is still at large in the carnival, he can attempt to sabotage the party's performance, which otherwise plays out as written in the adventure:

items: A {@creature Smoke Mephit|MM} that is part of a firebreather's act will begin to cough and sneeze uncontrollably as {@creature Kester the Kenku|TWC|Kester} uses {@spell Mage Hand} to tickle its nose. All party members on stage will be subject to its Cinder Breath ability, after which it will apologise profusely.
Using {@spell Minor Illusion}, a board reading "BOO" will appear above the party's heads, causing some of the audience to start jeering them.
{@creature Kester the Kenku|TWC|Kester} sneaks on stage, disguised as a {@creature Commoner}, and uses his Twilight Sleep ability to engulf one character in sleep-inducing gas mid-performance.
Disguised as a Witchlight Hand, Kester will brush by another party member and use {@spell Bestow Curse} to give them disadvantage on all Charisma checks.

entries.name: Hour 8: Crowning the Witchlight Monarch
entries: Most of the carnival's stars have a part to play in the coronation, which celebrates the joyous zeal of a single guest. The event plays out as follows:

items: As spectators take their seats in the Big Top, Dirlagraun the displacer beast escorts {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} from his wagon to the coronation, leaving Thaco the clown behind to guard the Staff Area.

{@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and Dirlagraun stand on the sidelines next to Candlefoot as {@creature Mister Light|TWC} gives an opening speech and the monarch is selected (see "Selecting a Monarch" below). Candlefoot holds the hatbox containing the monarch's crown.

{@creature Mister Witch|TWC} removes the crown of golden butterflies from the hatbox and places it on the monarch's head; {@creature Mister Light|TWC} knights the monarch with the {@item Witchlight vane|TWC}. Happy clowns shower all three in glitter.
Witch and Light escort the monarch on a circuit of the stage while Palasha the mermaid sings a joyous song and pixies flutter all around her.

When Palasha's song concludes, {@creature Mister Light|TWC} leads the monarch on a parade through the carnival, with the other guests following as Burly the bugbear sets off fireworks. Meanwhile, Dirlagraun escorts {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} back to his wagon.

entries.name: Selecting a Monarch
entries: Keep note of each time the party has done something to increase the mood of the carnival, such as rescuing the Dwarf on the Dragonfly Rides, saving Rubin from the Hall of Illusions, or participating in the Snail Race. In {@creature Mister Light|TWC|Mr. Light}'s speech, he will touch on all the things they have done during their night at the carnival, displaying a seemingly omniscient knowledge of the actions the party has taken! Then, he will activate his Witchlight Vane to select the Monarch.

{@creature Mister Light|TWC}'s {@item Witchlight vane|TWC} selects the monarch from the carnival's guests, spinning a thread of golden light that winds its way to the chosen reveler. If the mood of the carnival is positive, choose the character who improved the carnival's mood the most, or ask the players to agree on which of their characters should be crowned. If it's not appropriate for any of the characters to be crowned monarch, then a jubilant halfling bedecked in flowers is selected from the crowd. {@creature Mister Light|TWC} exudes cheerfulness and follows through with the ceremony regardless of who is chosen.

At the end of the celebration, as the carnival begins to wind down, the ceremonial crown teleports back into its hatbox. Candlefoot returns the hatbox to the Staff Area, handing it off to Thaco the clown, who stashes it in the wagon belonging to {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC}.

entries.name: Development
entries: The Witchlight Monarch gains the following charm (see "{@book Supernatural Gifts|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts}" in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for more information) and instantly becomes aware of its benefits:

entries.name: Charm of the Monarch
entries: You can sprout a pair of beautiful butterfly wings. As long as you have the wings, you gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed, and you gain a +5 bonus on all Charisma-based ability checks. These effects last for 1 hour. After you use this charm three times, it vanishes from you.

entries.name: Through the Looking Glass
entries: The characters receive an invitation to meet privately with {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} when the carnival's mood reaches either end of {@area the track|065|x} or if the characters impress {@creature Mister Light|TWC} during the {@area Big Top Extravaganza|0f0|x}.
Witch and Light send Burly the {@creature bugbear} (neutral good) to fetch the characters:
A bugbear wearing dungarees, fairy wings, and a helmet made from a jack-o'-lantern approaches you. "Follow me," he growls. "Management wants to see you."

With a wave of his hand, Burly creates an opening in the wall of thorns that surrounds the staff wagons (see "Staff Area" above) and leads the characters through it. If questioned about the nature of the meeting, Burly insists there's nothing to worry about. If the carnival's mood is good, he adds that his bosses are in high spirits.
If the characters follow Burly, read:

The bugbear leads you to a circle of wagons. Leaning against a particularly ostentatious wagon is an aging clown with a painted grin. He puffs on a bubble pipe and glares at you as the bugbear, ignoring the clown, opens the wagon's door and ushers you inside.
The clown is Thaco, a human {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hand} (chaotic neutral; see the stat block earlier in the chapter) and over-the-hill carnival attraction.

entries.title: Mister Witch and Mister Light don't like strangers eavesdropping on their private conversations

entries.name: Inside the Wagon

entries: A flamboyant elf grins from ear to ear as he welcomes you into the wagon with a theatrical bow. "Please come in, it's a delight to meet you all! I am {@creature Mister Light|TWC}, and this is my associate, {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}."
He gestures to a stocky elf lounging on a bunk. {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} nods to you and doffs his top hat.

{@creature Mister Light|TWC} gestures toward his scepter—the {@item Witchlight vane|TWC}—and explains that it picks up every nuance of emotion in the carnival. {@b If the carnival's mood is good}, Light expresses his gratitude for the cheer that the characters have brought to the carnival so far. {@b If the carnival's mood is bad}, he expresses his regret that the characters aren't having a delightful time and notes that, in turn, they're spoiling everyone's evening.
Witch and Light are eager to learn the characters' reasons for visiting the carnival. Witch and Light will also share the following information if asked:

items: If they are questioned about conversations that were overheard (see "{@area Witch and Light's Wagon|0d8|x}" above and "{@area Catching Kester|0e7|x}" below), Witch and Light admit they're not the carnival's original owners and took over management through an honest pact with the owner of another carnival.
If asked about Kester, Witch and Light say he's "a troublemaker from a competing carnival who just wants to stir up chaos and ruin everyone's fun.

entries: When the characters mention that they are looking for a fabled magic shop, {@creature Mister Light|TWC}'s eyes widen. Their response is further determined by the carnival's mood:

entries.name: If the carnival's mood is bad
entries: The carnival owners look at each other sceptically before informing the characters that only worthy carnival-goers are invited to partake of Mr. Garfield's splendid deals, and they have thus far proven to be the opposite. Mister Witch asks the adventurers {@i "By what right do you claim to be worthy of this invitation?"}
The characters may state their case. Make a Charisma check to convince the carnival owners that the characters should be allowed access to the fabled magic shop.

rows: DC 30

Mister Witch and Mister Light's eyes sparkle with agreement. Mister Witch: {@i "Masterfully said, young heroes."} Mister Light: {@i "We have clearly benefited greatly from your presence here tonight! You are indeed worthy!"}
DC 25

The carnival owners exchange curious glances. Mister Witch says {@i "You make a solid point, young adventurer."} Mister Light: {@i "I think they've proven their worth, Mister Witch, wouldn't you agree? And I do believe our the warlock friend would be amenable to having clients like these."}
DC 20

The carnival owners exchange unsure glances. Mister Witch says {@i "You make a half-way decent point, young adventurer."} Mister Light: {@i "I think we can let these transgressions slide this time, would you say, Mister Witch?"} Mister Witch: {@i [sigh] "Very well.  We'll show you the way."}
Fail

The carnival owners exchange annoyed glances. Mister Witch says {@i "You come to our wonderful carnival and ruin everyone's fun. You destroy our property, [list more offenses], and now you are demanding to receive and invitation to visit an exclusive magic shop, whose patronage is limited to only the most worthy individuals? I think not. I invite you to continue enjoying yourself at the carnival. Please understand that, if you cause any more trouble, we will be forced to cast you out."}

entries.name: If the carnival's mood is good

entries: Mister Light's eyes light up and he says "Ooo, more clients! Mr. Garfield will be pleased!  Interesting indeed that you are even aware of its existence, though you've clearly proven yourselves to be resourceful, and you have more than proven that you are most worthy of this exclusive invitation, my fair heroes!  Please, let me show you the hidden entrance!"
On the way out of the wagon and through the carnival, Mister Witch asks "Just what do you know of this magic shop you seek?"

Mister Witch and Mister Light are now willing to openly discuss Fantasy Costco with the adventurers. They acknowledge that the owner was at one time a Witchlight Hand who later became a magic performer at the carnival, before gaining enough power that he opted to leave the Witchlight Carnival's employ. The departure was on good terms, and when he came back to Mister Witch and Mister Light years later (8 years, to be exact) asking if they would help conceal a portal to his fantastic magic shop, they loved the idea and of course acquiesced to help their old friend. The carnival owners also know the following information, if asked:

items: {@b Where are we going?} The pocket dimension beyond the mirror is called {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}, wherein dwells the store owner, Garfield the Deals Warlock, who loves nothing more than to make a deal. Bring an open mind and a willingness to bargain, or bring coin, and lots of it.

{@b Time and space.} Time flows differently and unpredictably in this pocket dimension. Though the heros may only spend an hour or so on the other side, when they come back to this plane of existence, they may find that several days or only seconds have passed. And there's no guarantee that they'll land in exactly the same spot either.
{@b How to get back.} When the heros are ready to leave the pocket dimension, Garfield will manifest the same portal they entered through.

{@b What kind of "deals" does this merchant like to make?} From what the carnival owners have heard, pretty much anything is on the table. Legend has it that his clients have been known to trade Garfield their memories, their talents, and even years of their own life.

entries: The carnival owners lead them to the Hall of Illusions and march them inside:

As Witch and Light move through the Hall of Illusions, their reflections in the mirrors show them as gloomy shadar-kai children, with your own youthful reflections following behind. Soon, they call you to a halt. The mirrors now reflect everyone's true age.
{@creature Mister Light|TWC} adds in a hushed tone, "I must warn you. The deals... they're insane!"

entries.name: Stepping Through
entries: When a character recites Witch's rhyme while standing in front of their present-day reflection in the Hall of Illusions, read:
Mist swirls in the mirror, blotting out your reflection.

Any creature that touches the surface of the misty mirror is pulled through it and deposited in {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}. If a character tries to take either the {@item Witchlight watch|TWC} or the {@item Witchlight vane|TWC} through the mirror, the item drops to the floor as the character crosses the threshold. Neither item can be taken into the pocket dimension.
If {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} are both present, they wait until only one character remains and then impart the following information to that character:

entries.name: Dropping Hints
entries: This is your chance as a DM to give your player some prophetic guidance in their larger campaign quest here. A hint as to what direction they should take next, or a clue to solving a problem they will soon face.  If you can think of nothing to give them, you can just make up some nonsense and choose how to implement it later. For example: "when the time is right, follow the white rabbit".
