entries.name: Ticket Booth
entries: The booth where visitors buy their tickets is located at the main entrance.

A silver statue of a dancing faerie is mounted on the roof of this ticket booth and surrounded by fluttering butterflies. The booth is decorated with an animated depiction of the night sky, with shooting stars arcing across it.
An elderly goblin perches behind the ticket counter, peering at you quizzically through a spyglass. He lowers the spyglass and calls out to you: "Greetings, fair fairgoers!"

Visitors are expected to buy tickets at this booth. A ticket costs one apple blossom flower. Instead of buying their ticket with an apple blossom, a visitor can try to barter with the ticketer, Nikolas Midnight, a wrinkled {@creature goblin} (see "Bartering for a Ticket" below). For more information on Nikolas Midnight, see "{@area Roleplaying Nikolas|086|x}" below.

After giving the characters their tickets, Nikolas hands the group a map of the carnival and gives each character a pair of colorful cloth butterfly wings to wear. Nikolas explains that the butterfly wings must be worn to show the staff that the characters are paid attendees. They are now free to explore the carnival at their leisure.

entries.name: How the Tickets Work
entries: Nikolas explains that each ticket is good for eight attractions; characters who want to sample more of the carnival's offerings must buy another ticket. Most attractions in the carnival have a cost of 1 ticket punch, but the pub trivia is free. After the eighth punch, a ticket becomes a worthless keepsake.

entries.name: Sneaking Inside
entries: The carnival issues fake butterfly wings to every visitor who receives a ticket. Visitors are expected to wear their wings, or at least carry them around, while inside the carnival. The tickets and fake wings are theirs to keep.

Any character who tries to sneak into the carnival without a set of fake butterfly wings must succeed on a DC 16 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check or be spotted and approached by {@dice 1d3} {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hands} of any alignment (see the stat block earlier in the chapter). The hands ask to see the character's ticket; any character without a ticket is escorted to the main entrance and directed to the ticket booth. If the character runs away from the Witchlight hands, the hands don't bother giving chase, but the carnival's mood lowers by one step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). A character without butterfly wings who successfully sneaks into the carnival must repeat the check at the end of each hour.

entries.name: Bartering for a Ticket
entries: Any visitor who can't afford the price of a ticket or who doesn't want to pay for a ticket can make a fey pact with Nikolas instead. Each pact is a one-night-only deal that ends when the Witchlight Monarch is crowned (see "{@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x}" toward the end of the chapter). If a character chooses to enter into such a pact, roll on the Ticket Pacts table to determine the conditions. A character who barters for multiple tickets can have more than one pact in effect; if any table result comes up twice, choose a different result.

Any character who fulfills the conditions of a pact should be a strong contender for the title of Witchlight Monarch. A character who doesn't abide by the pact loses their ticket, which transforms into an ordinary bat and flaps away. In addition, the carnival's mood lowers by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

entries.caption: Ticket Pacts
rows: You must not tell a lie knowingly.
You must wear a crown of flowers and water it every hour without taking it off.
You must perform a short dance whenever you hear someone say your name.
You can't talk about your favorite subject.
You must carry around a small pumpkin as though it were a precious egg.
You must greet all trees with reverence.
You must compliment everyone you meet.
You must declare your love for unicorns at every opportunity.

entries.name: Roleplaying Nikolas
entries: Nikolas (lawful neutral) carries a spyglass and an ear horn, which he uses when talking to patrons. Nikolas plays on the fact that he is old when using these items, but it's all a ruse; he is as sharp as a thorn, and his instruments allow him to get the true measure of guests. In his hands, the spyglass and ear horn grant Nikolas advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks to discern lies and determine true intent. Characters who attempt to deceive Nikolas must succeed on a Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check contested by the goblin's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

If one or more characters seem intent on disrupting the carnival, Nikolas scribbles a brief note to that effect and hands it to an {@condition invisible} {@creature pixie} that lurks under the ticket counter. The pixie delivers Nikolas's message to {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}, who informs the carnival staff to keep a close eye on the group, and the carnival's mood lowers by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

entries.name: Big Top

entries: The roof of this tent reaches toward the night sky in three swooping peaks topped with spinning gold stars. Painted wooden panels on the tent walls whirl with colorful motion, displaying vibrant circus performances. The sound of music and laughter drifts out through the canvas door.
Customers can enter the Big Top for free.

The Big Top is the setting for two main events: the Big Top Extravaganza and the crowning of the Witchlight Monarch, both of which are described in the "{@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x}" section toward the end of the chapter. In the hours leading up to midnight, carnival barkers stationed throughout the fair declare, "Big Top Extravaganza tonight at midnight! Prepare to be delighted!" After midnight, these barkers shout, "Who will be crowned our Witchlight Monarch? Join us in the Big Top just before dawn to find out!"

Aside from those scheduled events, a variety of entertainers perform here. Colorful orbs of light dance in the lofts of the tent while magic spotlights highlight performers. Spectators watch the acts from rows of tiered wooden seats encircling the ring. You can randomly determine an act by rolling on the Big Top Acts table, or you can create new acts using the table's entries as inspiration.

entries.caption: Big Top Acts
rows: Tiny firefly circus managed by an ogre dressed like a djinni
Halfling contortionist who can fit inside a hatbox
Pixies racing chariots pulled by weasels (eight pixies and sixteen weasels in all)
Satyr fiddler whose music causes dancing plants to burst from the ground
Troupe of eight clowns launching themselves from a magic cannon
Tiefling fire-breather who summons capering magma mephits and smoke mephits that disappear after 1 minute
Goblin juggler who can catch and juggle any tiny objects tossed to her by the crowd (up to eight objects at a time)
Elf ballerina who dances with animated costumes that spring from a magic wardrobe

entries.name: Dressing Room
entries: The backstage area is a smaller, circular tent adjoining the Big Top. The curtained doorway between the Big Top and the dressing room is guarded by two {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hands} (chaotic good; see the stat block earlier in the chapter), who bicker over the appeal of the acts while sharing a bottle of pear cider. They allow only performers and other Witchlight hands to pass through the curtain but are so distracted by their arguing that any character can slip past them unseen with a successful DC 14 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check.

This dressing room is a scene of colorful clutter: tables strewn with makeup kits and glass jewelry, mirrors trimmed with glowing orbs of light, and chests of drawers and wardrobes spilling over with garments.
If a character searches the dressing room for something fun, roll on the Costumes and Accessories table to determine what they find.

entries.caption: Costumes and Accessories
rows: Wire headband fitted with a sparkling paper unicorn horn
Waistcoat with a chain of one hundred silk handkerchiefs tied together in one of its pockets
Casket of costume jewelry
Front and rear halves of a two-person unicorn costume
Retractable dagger (harmless)
Pair of stilts and long, bright purple trousers
Enough animated face paint for five applications; each application animates on the skin to create swirling patterns that last for 1 hour
Clown costume with fake butterfly wings

entries.title: A tiefling fire-breather entertains the crowd under the Big Top

entries.name: Bubble-Pop Teapot

entries: A twenty-foot-tall teapot rests on a wooden platform, its painted surface whirling with moving imagery of flying dragons breathing streams of bubbles. A door at the base of the teapot allows entry to its interior; those who enter emerge from the spout enclosed in a bubble that detaches to float off across the carnival. Seven goblins sits around the platform, sipping tea from mismatched porcelain cups.

This ride costs 1 ticket punch. The ride is managed by a friendly goblin noncombatant named Treaclewise (chaotic good), who wears bright yellow butterfly wings and carries a string of teaspoons on his belt. Seven more friendly goblins sit and chatter around the giant teapot while sipping tea. When the characters approach, Treaclewise gestures to a sign on his table that reads:
{@i Why crawl when you can walk}
{@i Why walk when you can fly?}
{@i Why be silent when you can talk}
{@i Why talk when you can rhyme?}

Treaclewise loves to talk in rhymes. When a character engages Treaclewise and speaks in a rhyme, Treaclewise will wiggle his hips happily and cause his belt of spoons to jangle loudly, as he laughs as though it's the funniest thing he's ever heard. If he ever gets stuck for a rhyme, Treaclewise will often invent pure nonsense words just to get his sentences to work!
If Treacelwise takes a shine to a character he may gift the character with a pouch of {@item scatterleaf tea|TWC}}.

entries.name: Scatterleaf Tea
entries: As an action, a creature can scatter these tea leaves on the ground in a 5-foot-radius circle, duplicating the effect of a {@spell protection from evil and good} spell that lasts for 10 minutes. To gain the spell's protection, a creature must stand in the circle of tea leaves. In addition, a cup of hot, delicious tea magically appears in the protected creature's hands. A pouch contains enough leaves for one use.

entries.name: Taking a Bubble Ride
entries: Any Large or smaller creature that enters the teapot is enveloped in a magic bubble that floats up through the teapot's spout and into the sky, granting its occupant wonderful aerial views of the carnival. When the bubble pops after 1 minute, the passenger floats gently to the ground. Each bubble can hold only one creature (the smaller the creature, the smaller its bubble), plus whatever the creature is wearing or carrying.

A character suspended in the bubble can make a DC 1 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check, gaining control of the bubble on a success. The character can then steer the bubble and pop it over any location on the carnival map. On a failed check, the character has no control over their bubble, and it pops over a random location. If a character tries to steer a bubble out of the carnival, it pops at the perimeter.

entries.name: Calliope

entries: A merry tune spills forth from an instrument on the back of a brightly painted wagon. A monkey wearing a cloak covered with buttons turns a handle at the wagon's rear, sending music into the air from rows of golden whistles. As you watch, a goblin dressed as a ladybug toddles up to you, rattling a tin cup.

The calliope can be heard throughout the carnival and is magically linked to the carnival's mood. When people are happy, it pipes along merrily, but it plays discordantly when the mood is low. Each of the calliope's whistles is imbued with magical gusts of wind, allowing it to play without end.

Ernest the monkey turns the handle of a piano roll; the punched holes in the roll of parchment provide the melody. Ernest has the mind of a middle-aged human, the result of a prank involving the organ grinder, his pet monkey, a leprechaun, and a great quantity of brambleberry wine. The organ grinder's mind was swapped with his monkey's, but the jest turned to disaster when his body ran off with the monkey's mind inside, never to be seen again. Ernest uses the {@creature baboon} stat block, but his Intelligence and Charisma are 10, and he can speak Common. His alignment is neutral good.
Ernest likes to collect buttons from the carnival's guests to sew onto his cloak. He has a rhyme for requesting them:
{@i Spare a button if you please,}
{@i I'll sew it next to all of these.}
{@i I offer nothing in its place,}
{@i Besides a smile upon my face.}
Marigold (chaotic good), the goblin dressed as a ladybug, collects the proffered buttons in a tin cup and delivers them to Ernest. Marigold is sprightly and often cajoles bystanders into dancing.

entries.name: Dragonfly Rides

entries: Huge lily pads rest on the surface of a pool glistening with phosphorescent algae. Giant dragonflies use the lily pads as landing platforms, buzzing loudly overhead with wings as brilliant as stained-glass windows, and alighting briefly to drop off and pick up excited passengers.
Near the entrance, a small, smiling tree turns your way and beckons you over. A red squirrel clings to its leafy canopy, peering at you suspiciously.

Northwind, a Prismeer native, is a carefree {@creature treant sapling|TWC} (see the accompanying stat block). Northwind's squirrel companion, Red, sizes up guests while keeping at least one beady eye on Northwind's acorns. Red is the beneficiary of a druid's {@spell awaken} spell; he uses the {@creature weasel} stat block but has an Intelligence of 10 and speaks Common.

entries.name: Dragonfly Riding
entries: Riding a dragonfly costs 1 ticket punch. There are eight {@creature Giant Dragonfly|TWC|giant dragonflies}, which are trained to fly their riders in a lazy figure eight around the carnival's thoroughfare, at a height of 20 feet. A character who tries to steer their dragonfly off course must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check to do so.

As the characters' first ride begins, shouts of alarm erupt from a nearby lily pad. A giant dragonfly has just taken off prematurely with a patron on its back: a middle-aged dwarf with a bright blue beard sits unfastened in his harness. Kester, a kenku trickster, used a {@spell speak with animals} spell to panic the dragonfly. Characters can spot Kester before he slips away with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check contested by the kenku's Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check. See "{@area Catching Kester|0e7|x}" later in the chapter if the characters try to confront him.

A character can calm the startled mount and guide it back to a lily pad with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. The carnival's mood rises by 1 step if a character succeeds on this check. Roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). If the characters fail to rescue the dwarf, he tumbles from the dragonfly's back; luckily, his fall is cushioned by a tent awning, and though he isn't badly hurt, the mood of the carnival lowers by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

entries.name: Questioning Northwind
entries: Northwind is terrible at keeping secrets. If questioned about the carnival, the treant loudly whispers the following bits of information, preceding each with "I'm not really supposed to talk about this, but..."

items: "{@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} aren't the carnival's original owners, y'know. They're not even from the Feywild! But it matters not an inch! We're all one big, happy family here!"
"The carnival can't run without {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}'s pocket watch—I hope he never loses it!"
"There's nothing {@creature Mister Light|TWC} likes more than a sea of smiling faces—if the carnival's happy, he's happy!"

entries.name: Feasting Orchard

entries: Music and mirth radiate from this park. The heady scents of flowers, mead, and berry pie waft through the air. Stilt-walkers pluck fruit from trees; musicians drum, pipe, and strum; and everywhere there is singing, dancing, and an inordinate amount of custard.

The Feasting Orchard bustles all through the night with the activity of storytellers, musicians, and acrobats. The feasting tables are lined with merrymakers, and dances spring up at the drop of a hat.

entries.name: Faerie Cake Eating Contest
entries: This contest runs repeatedly throughout the evening and costs 1 ticket punch to enter. The contest table is piled high with small, glazed cupcakes, each filled with a dollop of berry custard. The goal is simple: eat as many cupcakes as you can within 60 seconds.

A contestant can swallow a cupcake in about 3 seconds and safely eat as many cupcakes as 3 + its Constitution modifier; for each additional cake eaten, the contestant must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take {@dice 1d8} custard damage. Subtract custard damage from the contestant's hit points as normal. Any contestant reduced to 0 hit points by custard damage is unable to continue, loses the contest, and has custard splattered all over them. At the end of the contest, all contestants regain the hit points they lost from taking custard damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The prize for winning the contest is a cupcake that functions like a {@item potion of invisibility}. The whole cupcake must be eaten to gain its benefit.

entries.name: Ellywick Tumblestrum
entries: This gnome bard ("Tumblestrum" to her friends) is on stage in the Feasting Orchard when the characters first arrive. She sits on a stool, plucking the strings on her lute.

entries.name: Gondola Swans

entries: Enormous swans glide through the water here, pulling ornate wooden gondolas draped in flowers. The swans disappear into banks of silver mist as they wend their way down the river. A jetty extends ahead, at the end of which a waiting swan preens its feathers.
Riding a gondola costs 1 ticket punch. Each ride is an hour long; it starts and ends at the jetty, and the gondola follows the river that marks the perimeter of the carnival.

Each gondola is pulled by a {@creature giant swan|TWC}, which has the statistics of a {@creature giant eagle} except that it has no talons, can attack twice with its beak as an action, and speaks Common and Auran. If the characters approach the swan at the end of the jetty, she bows her head, introduces herself as Feathereen, and explains that she can take the characters along the river that encircles the carnival. Each gondola holds up to eight Medium creatures.
Feathereen is erudite and haughty. She asks the characters several metaphysical questions as they travel, such as these:

items: "How are you finding the Carnival? Anything interesting happen? I'm not a gossip, your secrets are safe with me."
"How do magic spells know how much diamonds cost? Why does Revivify bring someone back to life with 300gp worth of diamonds but not 299?"
"Do plants have souls? What do you think their afterlife is like?"
"In worlds so full of magic, is time an illusion?"
"How do I know you exist?"
"What is joy?"

entries: If the characters ignore Feathereen or make light of her questions, she rocks the gondola and tries to pitch her passengers into the water. Each occupant must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw to stay inside the boat.
Characters who impress Feathereen with their answers earn her respect; if she is questioned about the carnival, her gossipy nature is revealed, and she imparts the following information:

items: Feathereen saw the mime Candlefoot (see "Hall of Illusions") make a disastrous attempt to propose to the mermaid Palasha. "He was about to declare his love for the mermaid in front of everyone, when the words left him with a gasp! It was most unusual, and he hasn't spoken a word since. Palasha was very upset."

Feathereen enjoys late-night debates with the bugbear Burly (see "{@area Staff Area|0d5|x}" later in the chapter). "He has a profound mind and is simply wasted guarding the staff wagons. He misses his brother tremendously. No one knows what happened to Hurly, but everyone knows he never really fit in.)

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters annoy Feathereen, she is irritable for the rest of the evening, and the carnival's mood lowers by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). If pleased, she remains in high spirits, which raises the carnival's mood by 1 step (roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table}).

entries.name: Hall of Illusions
entries: A glass cabinet stands near the entrance to this tent. If the characters approach it, read the following boxed text aloud. If they investigate the tent first, skip ahead to "Approaching the Hall of Illusions."

A wooden mannequin of a grinning, raven-haired young woman in witch's attire and a green flowing cape hovers inside a glass cabinet. At the top of the cabinet, a sign reads "Tasha the Wizard—Known for Her Hideous Laughter."

A halfling couple holds hands as they approach the glass cabinet. One of the halflings is wearing butterfly face paint. As he drops to one knee and pulls a small box from his pocket, his sweetheart bursts into laughter and begins rolling on the ground. The halfling in face paint begins sobbing and darts into the nearby tent without getting his ticket punched.

Characters who succeed on a DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check recall that Tasha was one of the names reputedly used by Iggwilv the Witch Queen, a legendary archmage. Any creature that comes within 10 feet of the mannequin must succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or be affected as if by a {@spell Tasha's hideous laughter} spell. Whether the saving throw succeeds or fails, the creature can't be affected by the mannequin again.

The halfling in face paint is Rubin Sugarwood, and his halfling sweetheart is named Ween Sundapple; both are {@creature Commoner||commoners} (lawful good). Ween got too close to the glass cabinet and fell victim to its spell. If one or more characters follow Rubin into the Hall of Illusions, see "{@area Chasing Rubin|0ad|x}" below.
After recovering from the cabinet's spell, Ween remains outside the tent and calls out for Rubin, hoping he will return.

entries.name: Approaching the Hall of Illusions

entries: This large tent is painted with a mural of shifting images that show grinning faeries diving into pools of color. The helical stripes of the tent's pointed canopies rotate in spirals, and the whole display seems designed to befuddle onlookers. A clown dressed in muted garb stands at the tent's entrance, blinking at you.
Entering the tent costs 1 ticket punch.

The veil between the Material Plane and the Feywild is thinnest inside this hall of magical mirrors, and the door to the {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x} pocket dimension lies deep within. Thieves from The Hourglass Coven slip in and out of the tent as they desire, and most of the carnival staff prefer to give the attraction a wide berth, believing it to be jinxed or haunted.

entries.name: Candlefoot the Mime
entries: Candlefoot, a {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hand} (neutral good; see the stat block earlier in the chapter), is the reluctant ticket-puncher at the Hall of Illusions, and he does all he can to avoid entering the hall. All the color has leached out of his skin, hair, eyes, and apparel, giving him a strangely monochromatic look. And his problems don't end there.
A kenku named Kester stole Candlefoot's voice, so he communicates through mime. If the characters give him a writing implement and some parchment, he can also write out his thoughts.

entries.name: A Fey Romance
entries: When the mermaid Palasha (see "{@area Silversong Lake|0bd|x}" later in the chapter) joined the Witchlight Carnival, Candlefoot discovered that her songs had the power to bring back his coloration. (The change lasts only as long as he can hear her sing.) This surprised them both, and when the pair met, they fell in love. Recently, Candlefoot was about to propose to Palasha when his voice was snatched by Kester. If questioned, Candlefoot tries to explain his sorry circumstances through mime and asks the characters to help him recover his voice from Kester so he can go through with his proposal.

Here's a fantastic opportunity for you to explore your hidden talents as a mime. To indicate that he has lost his voice, Candlefoot might move his lips, then shake his head while holding a hand up to one ear. He might bob his head and flap his arms like a bird to indicate that Kester is the culprit. He doesn't know where the kenku is, but he knows he has been causing mischief throughout the carnival and sometimes uses magic to conceal his true form.
If the characters agree to help Candlefoot, he performs a few delightful magic tricks for their amusement using his {@spell prestidigitation} cantrip, which he can cast without the verbal component.

entries.name: Inside the Hall of Illusions
entries: Tall mirrors line the interior walls of the tent. The mirrors near the entrance reflect onlookers in their youth; the images grow steadily older, until the mirrors deep within the hall reflect onlookers in their twilight years. As the characters scrutinize their reflections, ask the players to describe what their characters looked like as children and what they might look like in old age.

When the correct incantation is spoken aloud in front of any of the hall's mirrors, the mirror transforms into a portal to the Feywild domain of Prismeer (see "{@area Through the Looking Glass|0f8|x}" at the end of the chapter for more information).

entries.name: Chasing Rubin
entries: If the characters chase after Rubin when he enters the hall, Candlefoot looks shocked but doesn't follow them inside.
Any character who spends 1 minute searching for Rubin finds him with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. The halfling is gazing worriedly into a mirror at his youthful reflection.
If the characters fail to find Rubin after 3 minutes, they come upon his ring on the floor inside the hall.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters reunite the halfling couple, Ween accepts Rubin's proposal, and the carnival's mood rises by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). If Rubin and Ween are not reunited, the mood of the carnival lowers by 1 step as word of Rubin's disappearance spreads (roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table}).

entries.name: Pixie Kingdom

entries: A copse of oak trees shelters a miniaturized fairground. At its heart, a hamster runs inside a tiny Ferris wheel, encircled by minuscule wagons and candy stalls. A pixie sits cross-legged in the hollow of a tree at the entrance to this realm.

The {@creature pixie} introduces himself as Jeremy Plum and does his best to persuade the characters that the Pixie Kingdom is the best attraction the carnival has to offer. Entry to the attraction costs 1 ticket punch.

Jeremy encourages the characters to adopt pixie names before entering; Allow your players to come up with their own Pixie names for their characters, with Jeremy Plum reacting favorably to the most ridiculous ones. The silliest name receives a reward from him: a {@item Potion of Advantage|TWC|Potion of Advantage}. Alternatively, refer to the table below for ideas.  The carnival's mood rises by 1 step if all the characters use their adopted pixie names while in the attraction. Roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

entries.name: Pixie Names

rows: Brightmite
Cobweb
Cotton Candy
Dimple
Jellybean Starfish
Panache
Puddlemud
Toadhop

entries: Whether or not the characters agree to adopt their pixie names, Jeremy sprinkles {@item pixie dust|TWC} on them. Jeremy also presents each character with a potion that, when consumed within the boundary of the Pixie Kingdom, reduces the imbiber's size to Tiny for 1 hour, or until the imbiber wants the effect to end. Until the effect ends, the Tiny character has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws, and the character's weapons deal {@dice 2d4} less damage (this change can't reduce the damage below 1).

entries.name: Exploring the Kingdom

entries: The Pixie Kingdom is a tranquil oasis compared to the rest of the bustling carnival. The air is filled with the aroma of blackberry wine and flower blossoms. Eight brightly painted doorways are nestled in the bark at the bases of the surrounding trees.

Twelve {@creature Pixie||pixies} reside here during carnival hours. They are friendly, curious, and eager to ask new arrivals all sorts of questions. The characters are free to explore the kingdom and experience the following wonders:

items: One character at a time can ride Pinecone, an excitable pug that listens only to pixies.
The kingdom's centerpiece is a pixie palace made entirely of old cocoon husks beautifully woven together.
Characters can dine on cucamelon sandwiches and thimbleberry tarts inside one of the pixie cottages.
Characters can ride the wheel, which is powered by a talkative hamster named Biscuit. An {@spell awaken} spell cast on the hamster gives it an Intelligence of 10 and the ability to speak Common.

entries: Characters who spend time talking to the pixies or Biscuit learn the following rumors:

items: "Everyone's on the lookout for a kenku troublemaker, but he's using magic to disguise himself."
"Candlefoot the mime and Palasha the mermaid are in love. On top of that, Candlefoot's lost his voice. Is that part of his act?"
"Burly the bugbear often talks philosophy with one of the gondola swans. That bugbear has brains as well as brawn."

entries.name: Playing Hide-and-seek
entries: After a short while, the characters are invited to play a game of hide-and-seek, organized by two {@creature Pixie||pixies}: the game's friendly supervisor, Honeymint, and a seeker named Starbug.

Each character who plays the game makes a Wisdom ({@skill Stealth}) check to hide (see the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} for rules on skills with different abilities). Starbug finds the character who has the lowest check result, at which point all the remaining characters move to new hiding places and make another check. The game continues until only one character remains hidden; this character is declared the winner and is awarded a packet of {@item pixie dust|TWC}, with two leaves as the propeller blades. No character can win this prize more than once.
The characters can hide anywhere in the Pixie Kingdom, but Honeymint points out the following hiding spots before the game begins:

items.name: Biscuit's Wheel
items.entry: This wooden wheel has eight wicker carriages. Biscuit, the hamster who trundles around inside the contraption that turns the wheel, is very talkative. Offering food to the hamster is one way to keep him quiet.

items.name: Flower Bed
items.entry: This area is home to several talking wildflowers. They're rather conceited and bicker over which of them has the silkiest petals and the finest aroma. Flattery can silence their bickering.

items.name: Heron's Nest
items.entry: An awakened heron named Beatrice, who enjoys talking about the weather, roosts in a clump of long grasses and might allow characters to hide in her nest if they ask nicely.

entries: Any character who tries to hide in one of these locations must succeed on a DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check to shush the creatures there. Success grants advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in that location.

entries.name: Pub Trivia

entries: As you approach this circular tent-tavern, you hear social conversation and laughter from within, the clink of glassware and wooden mugs, and the periodic amplified voice of a goblin announcing what sound like team names, including "Din of Thieves" and "Ligers".

There's one empty table in the otherwise packed tavern tent.  A small goblin in a dapper suit is M.C.'ing the event, announcing teams' names as they sign up for the free pub trivia contest, held every hour or two.  He announces one more name as the players enter the tent, "The Fantastic Feathered Phandalin Five", and then declares that there's room for {@i one more team} if anyone have the stones to enter the competition. Just step right up to register.

The adventurers should approach the tiny M.C. goblin to sign up for the trivia game.  They are asked to provide a team name, and while the goblin chalks their name onto the slate board, they see the other team names. (see the {@link "Pub Trivia Team Names"|0ee2|x} table below)
Once the players register as a team, read the following aloud:
The goblin finishes scratching your team name onto the board and whirls around to the packed tavern and announces:

"...Registration is now CLOSED! We have a full roster of fearless braniacs ready to do battle in the arena of knowledge! And now down to business.  The rules of the game are fairly straightforward, but there are some special tricks you can pull, so competitors, listen up!"
Explain the following rules:

items: There are 3 rounds of 8 questions each
Questions in Rd 1 are worth 1 pt each
Questions in Rd 2 are worth 2 pts each
Questions in Rd 3 are worth 3 pts each
After 3 rounds, two teams with the most points will go head-to-head in a final one-question round -- the leading team gets to choose the category.
The winner gets a fabulous prize and braggin' rights!
{@b {@i POWER-UPS}}: each team gets 3 power-ups that can each be used on one question per round:
{@b {@i Go it alone.}} A correct answer is worth double! But only one person from your team can answer, without help! You must decide {@i before} the question is asked.
{@b {@i Sending-stone-a-friend.}}  Don't worry, they've got the other sending stone in hand just for this event.
{@b {@i Bonus Question.}}  Take a bonus follow-up question for an additional 1 point. No penalty for getting the bonus question wrong.

entries.name: Running the Trivia Game
entries: The DM will need to keep a tally of each team's score for each round. Every time a trivia question is asked, also roll a {@dice d20} for each competing team and add their INT modifier (see: {@table Pub Trivia Team Names|TWC}) to determine their results.  An 11 or higher means they answered that question correctly. A natural 20 means that team also got an additional point for that round by answering the bonus followup question correctly. {@i Tip pre-rolling all of the competing teams' results for all rounds before you run this session will speed things up immensely.}
Also be sure to keep track of what power-ups your players have used per round.
For each question, follow this step-by-step:

items: Before asking the question, ask if the players want to use their Go It Alone power-up.
Read the question aloud.
Repeat the quesetion aloud. Then, give them a time limit (say, 60 seconds).
{@i If you have not pre-rolled all of your competing team's results, you'll want to quickly roll them during this time.}
{@i During this time, consider reminding them they can use a phone-a-friend power-up.}
Be sure to always ask for their {@b "final answer"}.
Announce whether they got it right or not. {@i If they answered correctly, consider reminding them they can use their power-up to ask for a bonus followup question worth 1 point.}
Announce how the other teams did, as the goblin M.C. writes the results on the board.

entries: Periodically throughout the game, roll on the {@table Random Events Between Trivia Questions|TWC} table below.  Consider allowing your players' reactions to some of these events to affect the overall mood at the carnival, or to grant them buffs or debuffs during the trivia game as appropriate.

At the end of 3 rounds, the top 2 teams square off in one final round, consisting of just one (long) question.  If there are multiple teams tied for second place, go ahead and allow more than 2 teams into the final round, as it won't effect the mechanics of the game.  The leading team chooses the category for the final question.

For the final question, read the prompt for "Question #9" of the selected trivia category.  The answer to the question will be in the form of listing "all possible" correct answers.  Each correct answer will be worth 1 point. For an NPC team, roll a {@b d(X-Y) + Y} to determine their results, where Y is their INT modifier, and X = the total number of possible correct answers.  So, for ex: if the team has a modifier of +1 and there are 10 possible correct answers, you would roll a {@dice d9+1}.
The winning team all get to reach into the goblin's Carnival Prize sack and grab one prize!  Roll a {@dice d12} on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table} to determine the prize.

entries.name: Silversong Lake

entries: Mist gathers at the banks of a shimmering lake. Near its center, a mermaid lounges in a giant bowl, singing a glorious, haunting song that captivates spectators on the lakeshore. In response, the lake water coalesces into magical sculptures that whirl around her as she performs.
It costs nothing to visit the lake and behold its star attraction: the {@creature merfolk} Palasha (chaotic good). Audiences crowd the lakeside just to witness her beauty and hear her song.

Palasha is no ordinary mermaid. Her singing has the ability to emulate the effects of a {@spell control water} spell. Once per day, as an action, she can also summon a {@creature swarm of Quippers} that obeys her commands until it disappears after 1 minute.

Palasha is in love with Candlefoot (see "{@area Hall of Illusions|0a6|x}") but finds it tragic that he has lost his voice. She can't face seeing him after his very public marriage proposal went awry. The mermaid is also fiercely devoted to the carnival. "We are an impossibility in an impossible universe," she tells colleagues and strangers alike, with great pride.

entries.name: Feathered Heckler
entries: This event occurs the first time the characters watch Palasha perform. Kester, the kenku trickster, snakes through the crowd, using {@spell disguise self} and Mimicry to pose as different hecklers. After three mean-spirited jeers, the mermaid falters in mid-song, leaps out of her bowl, and darts off, heading downriver. Her abrupt departure causes the carnival's mood to lower by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}").

Characters who try to identify the hecklers can spot Kester in his current guise with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check contested by the kenku's Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check. See "{@area Catching Kester|0e7|x}" later in the chapter if the characters try to corner him.

entries.name: Helping Palasha
entries: If she is driven from Silversong Lake by heckling, Palasha takes refuge in the river near the Hall of Illusions. To coax her back to the lake, the characters must perform an act of gallantry, such as helping Candlefoot find his lost voice.

If the characters persuade Palasha to return to the lake and resume her performance, the carnival's mood rises by 2 steps. Roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). Palasha offers a singing lesson to any characters who helped her.

entries.name: Small Stalls

entries.title: Catch the Dragon by the Tail

entries: The fair boasts several small stalls, each run by a {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hand} (variable alignments; see the stat block earlier in the chapter). Some of the stalls sell sweet snacks and drinks. For 1 ticket punch, a customer can buy a snack served on a large flower petal or a beverage served in a fist-sized snail shell. The offerings include:

items: Blue-frosted cupcake
Candied apple on a stick
Euphoreo cookie (saucer-sized cookies dusted with particles of faerie dragon euphoria gas)
Eveningberry wine (a sweet, nonalcoholic drink)
Faerie bell nectar (harvested from faerie bell flowers)
Pixie tarts (powdered candy in little cups)
Sugar-glazed button mushrooms
Tree sap lollipop

entries: The remaining stalls offer games and contests that cost 1 ticket punch apiece. A handful of games are summarized in the Carnival Games table and described below, and you can create others as you see fit using these as models.

entries: If a character wins a prize playing a game, roll a {@dice d12} on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table} to determine the prize.

entries.name: Almiraj Ring Toss

entries: "This almiraj is no mirage. Adorn its horn with rings to win a prize!"

This game involves tossing rings over the horn of a wooden statuette of an almiraj (a cute, bunny-like creature with a horn like a unicorn's). The almiraj teleports around on a tabletop, making it hard to score a success. A participant gets three rings. Tossing a ring over the almiraj's horn requires a successful DC 18 Dexterity check. Three successful tosses earn one roll on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table}.
Using Mage Hand or similar tricks to cheat when throwing the rings is allowed (even encouraged), and lets the character roll at advantage. Encourage creativity!

entries.name: Catch the Dragon by the Tail

entries: "Prizes! Prizes! Prizes! Catch the faerie dragon by the tail and win a piece of its hoard!"

While blindfolded and standing in a booth, a participant must grab the tail of an elusive, giggling {@creature Faerie Dragon (Red)||red faerie dragon} that flutters around them. The participant has three chances to succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Someone who succeeds on the check catches the dragon by the tail and rolls once on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table}.

Similarly to the Almiraj Ring Toss, cheating creatively is celebrated. A participant can be given the Help action by another character shouting instructions from the sidelines or give themselves Advantage on the Perception check by using a spell like {@spell Detect Magic} to find the Faerie Dragon while blindfolded.

entries.name: Gnome Poetry Contest

entries: "Sound the chime, it's time to rhyme! You bring the poem! We'll bring the gno-em!"

A participant must outperform a gnome in a best-of-five poetry contest. Doing so requires three successful DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Performance}) checks in five or fewer attempts. Someone who wins the contest rolls once on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table}, or twice if they succeeded all five times without failing a check.

The Gnome running this stall will start off the contest with a line of their own, then the next person has to complete the poem with a rhyme. A successful rhyme allows the player to make a DC15 Performance check to get a favorable reaction from the Gnome. Allow the party to take turns as they like jumping in with rhyming lines. One success means everyone who participated wins a prize: five successes gets everybody two prizes!
Gnome Rhymes:

items: No-one's better at poems than artistic gno-ems, but this one thinks they can rhyme...
Fun and games galore are in store: fly in a bubble or swim on a swan...
The main event is held in a tent, at midnight come to the Big Top...
Have your fill at the carnival, run by Misters Witch and Light...
Such a shame it's the end of the game, but the night is still young...

entries.name: Goblin Wrestling

entries: "Strong folks! Test your mettle in a goblin wrestle!"

A Small participant has to pin an unarmed {@creature goblin} (lawful good), while a Medium participant has to pin one goblin while wrestling two of them. Winning the game requires a successful Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check contested by the goblin; two goblins working together make one check with advantage. Resolve a tie by rerolling. A victorious participant earns one roll on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table}.

The two Goblins who run this stall are brothers called Borg and Morg. They will flex their wiry green muscles and show off to anyone they can, loudly boasting about how powerful they are and various creatures they will claim to have wrested and won: Dragons, Giants, and even a Tarrasque.
Should a player defeat them, they will claim to have let them win because they like them, as they only showed one percent of their true power.

entries.name: Guess the Number of Feathers

entries: "Birds of a feather? How about feathers of a bird? Step right up and guess how many feathers festoon this fiendish fowl!"

A participant gets three tries to guess the number of feathers on one of a group of caged {@creature Cockatrice||cockatrices}. Someone who succeeds on a DC 22 Intelligence check guesses correctly and earns one roll on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table}, or a roll with Advantage (roll twice and pick your favorite prize of the two) if the successful check occurs on the first attempt.

The Cockatrices in the cages are unruly and belligerent: they hardly stay still long enough for anyone to get an accurate count. A DC 15 {@skill Animal Handling} check will calm them down enough for a player to get Advantage on their check, however.

entries.name: Outstare the Cyclops

entries: "What do you do when the eye of the cyclops falls upon you? You stare right back if you've got the stamina!"

Winning this game requires a participant to outstare an illusory cyclops. Whoever blinks first loses. To win the game, the contestant must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution check. Someone who wins the game receives a prize, determined by rolling once on the {@table Carnival Prize|TWC|Carnival Prizes table}.

The illusory face of the Cyclops will scowl and pull faces, attempting to throw the challenger off. The player can attempt to mirror this, and with a successful DC 20 {@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Performance} check, they can pull some faces so grotesque they gain Advantage on their DC 14 Constitution save to outstare the Cyclops as it blinks in surprise.

entries.name: Snail Racing

entries: The grandstands next to this racecourse are filled with cheering fairgoers ringing bells, swinging rattles, and waving flags. On the starting line, eight giant snails are having their shells scrubbed by pixies.
Above the circular course, a wooden gantry hangs from the branches of a central tree, where two goblins officiate the proceedings.
Snail racing is a highly competitive, fast-paced sport that draws a lively crowd. Characters can participate in the race as snail jockeys, but it costs 1 ticket punch to enter.

If at least half the characters participate in a snail race, the carnival's mood rises by 1 step. Roll on the {@table Mood Rises|TWC|Mood Rises table} (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}"). If anyone breaks the rules, the mood lowers by 1 step (roll on the {@table Mood Lowers|TWC|Mood Lowers table}).

entries.name: Snails and Pixies
entries: Each of the eight {@creature Giant Snail|TWC|giant snails} is assigned a crew of three {@creature Pixie||pixies} to prepare it for a race. The snails are unusually fast, wear colored caparisons, and have numbered saddles strapped to their shells. Their racing numbers, names, and team colors are given in the Giant Snails table.
