entries.title: The giant snail race is one of the carnival's most popular attractions.

entries.name: Snail Racing Rules
entries: Every snail needs a jockey, and any saddles not filled by characters are filled by other attendees (use the {@creature commoner} stat block to represent these NPCs). All the snails and their riders begin at the start line; fireworks signal the start of the race, after which the riders race their snails to the finish line.

On a whiteboard or notepad, jot down the giant snails, their numbers, and their riders. Next to the names, keep a running total of how far each snail travels in feet during the race. The course is 480 feet long.
Have the Goblin referee announce this before the race:
"Here are the rules: no magic, and no contact. If anyone is caught cheating, you're out! But if you're not caught... good for you!"

If any competitors wish to cast spells or sabotage other players they may do so with Sleight of Hand checks contested by the referees' Perception (10). If any of the other players spot them they can call them out to the referees and get them instantly disqualified!
During the Race

items: Round One: one of the other contestants (a Commoner) will try to cast {@spell Guidance} on themselves.
Round Three: the Commoner in last place casts {@spell Longstrider} on their Giant Snail for a speed boost.

Round Five: the Commoner in last place attempts to cast {@spell Minor Illusion} to create a huge pile of salt on the track in front of whoever is in the lead. This can be ignored with a successful DC 10 {@skill Investigation} check to see through the illusion: otherwise, the victim loses a round of movement.

entries.name: Racing Rules
entries: The race is divided into 6-second rounds. Once the race begins, the snails move along the track at remarkable speed, each one covering 80 feet per round by itself. Without riders, the snails are an even match, but a jockey can try to improve a snail's performance by patting its shell or speaking words of encouragement at it.

Initiative rolls are unnecessary. Once per round, each jockey can make a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a successful check, the jockey's snail moves an extra 10 feet that round, or 20 feet if the check succeeds by 5 or more. On a failed check, the jockey's snail moves 10 feet slower that round, or 20 feet slower if the check fails by 5 or more. The race ends when one or more snails travel the 480 feet needed to cross the finish line.

If two or more snails cross the finish line in the same round, determine the winner of the race by having those snails' jockeys each roll a {@dice d20}. The highest roll determines the winner, with one snail narrowly claiming victory. If the roll for first place is tied, the race ends in a tie, and each winning jockey receives the first-place prize (see "Prizes" below).

Signs posted in the stands and along the racetrack warn that neither jockeys nor spectators may influence the outcome of a race by using magic or by harming other jockeys or snails. Any jockey who openly does so is disqualified, as is the jockey's snail. A spectator caught doing so is escorted from the carnival by {@dice 1d4} {@creature Goblin||goblins} (lawful good) who are watching the crowd closely for troublemakers.

entries.name: Surprises
entries: At the start of each round after the first, roll a {@dice d8} and consult the Snail Race Surprises table to determine if something unexpected happens that round. When a surprise occurs, determine which snail is affected by rolling a {@dice d8}.

entries.caption: Snail Race Surprises
rows: No surprise.
One random snail gets a stitch, reducing its speed by 40 feet this round.
A spectator throws a head of lettuce at one random snail. The snail stops to eat the lettuce and doesn't move at all this round.
One random snail is bolstered by the cheering crowd and moves an extra 20 feet this round.

The saddle on one random snail comes loose and falls off. The snail's jockey must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw to remain atop the snail. On a failed save, the jockey falls off, and the snail continues the race on its own.

entries.name: Prizes
entries: The jockey whose snail wins the race receives a {@item potion of advantage|TWC}. The jockey whose snail comes in last receives a consolation prize, provided they weren't disqualified. The consolation prize is a magic wand that allows its holder to cast the {@spell dancing lights} cantrip once. Once used to cast this spell, the wand turns into a tulip.

entries.name: Staff Area

entries: A tangled wall of thorns surrounds a cluster of wagons lit by lanterns. This caravan is barely visible through the thicket.

The carnival's wagons are located behind the Big Top, protected by a 20-foot-high, 5-foot-thick wall of thorns. When a member of the carnival staff stands within 1 foot of the wall, the thorns part to form an 8-foot-high, 4-foot-wide doorway in front of the staff member. This door remains open for 10 seconds, then disappears as thorny vines fill the opening once more. The wall is magical and also impervious to damage. The wall grants {@book three-quarters cover|PHB|9|Cover} to creatures behind it.

A creature can move through the wall of thorns, albeit slowly and painfully. It costs 8 feet of movement to move through 1 foot of the wall. The first time a creature enters the wall on a turn or ends its turn there, it must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Whenever a creature ends its turn in the wall, trumpet-shaped flowers burst from the brambles nearby and honk an alarm that is audible up to 50 feet away.

entries.name: Circle of Wagons
entries: Enclosed by the wall of thorns is a circle of eight brightly painted wagons, one of which is a glass-enclosed water tank for Palasha the mermaid. The fanciest of the remaining seven wagons belongs to {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC}.

The perimeter inside the wall of thorns and outside the circle of wagons is patrolled by a {@creature bugbear} named Burly (neutral good), who leaves his post once during the evening to participate in the {@area Big Top Extravaganza|0f0|x}.  While on patrol, Burly wears a large jack-o'-lantern on his head, as one would wear a helmet, in addition to his dungarees and fake fairy wings.

The central area enclosed by the wagons is guarded by Thaco the clown, a human {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|TWC|Witchlight hand} (chaotic neutral; see the stat block earlier in the chapter) who is loyal only to {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}. He usually sits right outside the door to Witch and Light's wagon, blowing bubbles with his bubble pipe.
Burly and Thaco dislike each other, so they don't fraternize while on guard duty.
Characters caught snooping around the wagons without an escort are evicted from the carnival and must find a way to sneak or barter their way back in.

entries.name: Witch and Light's Wagon
entries: {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC} (see their stat blocks earlier in the chapter) are in their wagon throughout the evening, except during the Big Top Extravaganza (which Light attends and Witch does not) and the crowning of the Witchlight Monarch (which they both attend). See {@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x} later in the chapter for more information.
Refer to the "Carnival Owners" section for more information about Witch and Light.
Characters who sneak up to the wagon while it's occupied can overhear Witch and Light talking:
Two contrasting voices emanate from the wagon.
{@i Mister Witch, in a low and gravelly voice:} "You need to find a way to calm down."
{@i Mister Light, in a high-pitched, shrill voice:} "I'll calm down when that kenku pest is gone."
{@i Witch}: "He'll tire out soon enough and be on his way."
{@i Light}: "I hope you're right."

From there, the conversation shifts to the current mood of the carnival and ideas for new carnival acts or attractions ("The catoblepas didn't work out, but maybe we can buy a giraffe and paint it blue. Or we could teach Northwind how to play the fiddle.")

If the characters disturb Witch and Light in their wagon without being invited, jump ahead to the "{@area Inside the Wagon|0e0|x}" encounter described later in the chapter, skipping over the lead-in with Burly and Thaco.

entries.name: Searching the Wagon
entries: {@creature Mister Witch|TWC}'s bunk is neat and unadorned. {@creature Mister Light|TWC}'s bunk is gaudy and messy, with costumes strewn everywhere. Characters who search through the gear find a hatbox containing the crown of the Witchlight Monarch; this splendid crown of gold butterflies teleports back to its hatbox at the end of each evening and is ceremoniously produced from its box during the monarch's coronation (see "{@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x}" later in the chapter).

Any character who searches the wagon for secret compartments finds one with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. The compartment is located in a bench and contains a tiny, bejeweled chest worth 50 gp. This chest is a replica of a much larger chest hidden on the Ethereal Plane (with the help of a {@spell Leomund's secret chest} spell). While holding the replica chest, {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} can use an action to summon the larger chest. He can send the larger chest back to the Ethereal Plane by using an action and touching both the chest and the replica.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest hidden on the Ethereal Plane (which is worth 5,000 gp) contains recent earnings (210 sp and 70 gp), a {@item potion of diminution}, a {@item potion of growth}, and a {@item potion of advantage|TWC}. The potions are not labeled, but {@creature Mister Witch|TWC} knows which is which.

entries.name: Overview
entries: Garfield the Deals Warlock is the sales associate at the Fantasy Costco and handles all of the buying and selling. If a customer does not have the money to pay for an item, Garfield will still accept payment in body parts and fluids. He's also been known to trade for other precious things... memories, years of one's life, talents, favors, etc.  But of particular note to adventurers is his willingness to accept XP and other stats as payment in place of gold pieces.  He appears to be the only person that works there.
Read the following aloud after the party steps through the portal:

A swirling vortex of blue light fills in the mirror before you.  As you step into it, you feel a tingling sensation.  Your boot meets a stone floor on the other side, and you lean through the yawning portal, the rest of your party following. Leaving the crisp night air of the carnival, your face is greeted with a flood of warmth and the smell of inscense. The sudden temperature change makes you want to shed a layer or two. As the last of your party steps out of the swirling portal, it shrinks behind you with a shlurping sound like the last few drops of a milkshake being sucked up through a straw.

Upon immediate entry, you can see a series of ever-burning candles in sconces adorning the walls, each one burning a slightly different color, all of them flickering like there's wind when there's none.  Inside the chamber you can see shelves that have several small trinkets laid out, including a jar of buzzing bees, various rings, a bedazzled comb with the "Kirkland" brand name stamped on it, and high atop one shelf, a long blade that seems to ooze a black ichor. It looks simultaneously powerful and hideous. And many other items. In the back behind a desk there appear to be more shelves with books and books and more books. You see only one figure in the room, standing behind the desk, who turns around to make your appearance. You see a large, seven-foot tall humanoid figure. His short, smooth, fine orange fur puffs up a little bit as his eyes meet yours. You can also now see he's holding a cat-like critter with wings, stroking it's head as it purs. The figure's physicality is slightly hunched and there's just a big ol' smile on the face.

"Ah! New customers, fantastic! Greetings and welcome to Fantasy Costco, where all your dreams come true! Have we got a DEAL for YOU!" He pauses for dramatic effect. "You must be very special indeed to have found my magic shop!  It is therefore my absolute pleasure to make your acquaintance!  My name is Garfield the Deals Warlock!" He hands you a sharp looking business card. "How may I help you today?"
Garfield is happy to converse with the party. He is wise, witty, and cunning. If the heroes inquire about any of the following, here's what Garfield knows (or is willing to tell them):

items: {@b Where {@i are} we exactly?}: In a pocket dimension between worlds! Like a moon orbits a planet, we're kind of "orbiting" the Feywild right now.
{@b Do you live here?}: Sure do! I never venture outside my realm these days.
{@b Why did you set up shop in a pocket dimension?}: Security mainly. Pretty hard to steal from a place you can't find. And I've got plenty worth stealing.
{@b Who else works here?}: Just me! And little Pocket here.
{@b What is this creature called?}: Oh, Pocket?  She's a tressym from the northern city of Everlund. Adorable little kitty isn't she?

{@b So, is there a {@i Mrs.} Garfield the Deals Warlock?}: Married to my work, you might say!  Although Pocket here bosses me around enough that I may as well be {@i pussy-whipped}! [chuckles cheesily]

{@b How do you know the carnival owners?}: Oh we go way back!  I myself used to be a Witchlight Hand (one of the carnival workers).  Then I graduated to more serious matters and found my niche: making {@i deeeeeals!} And after a while, once I started really dealing in powerful items, I had to limit admittence to my shop. {@creature Mister Witch|TWC|Mr. Witch} and {@creature Mister Light|TWC|Mr. Light} offered me a reliable way to do so.  Isn't it a fun way to screen my customers?!
{@b Can we buy back any years of Madryck Roslof's life?}: See: {@area Resolving the Old Man's Quest|439|x} below.

{@b Okay, I hear you like to make deals? What's the most unusual deal you've made?}: Oh quite, yes! Only the very rich could afford most of my wares. But I do so love to take other forms of payment! The most interesting deal would have to be that one very charming young lad who offered to buy one of {@footnote my trinkets|If they must know, the trinket was an alchemy jug. Yeah the young man was a BIG fan of mayonaisse. Pretty gross.} with what he called "his very Charisma". He's a surly grump of a hermit these days, while I'm quite enjoying using his charasmatic talents as my own!
{@b Can we BUY stats? Like XP?}: Hell to the nah.  Garfield collects them for himself.  He does not sell them!

{@b Here's our quest... Will you come fight with us?}: Hmm, I think not! If I joined every adventuring band of heroes that tried to recruit me, I wouldn't be around long. Nope, Garfield intends to stay put, make a profit, and keep collecting my marvelous trasures.

{@b What are you planning to do with all this stuff, if not use it?}: Oh the baubles and trinkets of my shop may not be of much use to me here in my little pocket realm, but it's a means to acquire more precious things. I've scraped together enough years of life from destitute customers, for instance, that I shall live for hundreds more years before I even need to think about bargaining for more.

entries.name: Resolving the Old Man's Quest
entries: If/when the heroes ask Garfield about trading the Old Man's ring for some of his life back, he will regretably inform them that it's too late for the old man. He has already died. Or he will by the time they leave this dimension. Same difference; time flows differently here.  Besides, Garfield will only offer coin as payment to sellers.

But he'd be happy to offer them 300 gp for the nifty little ring he gave them, after all it's theirs to do with what they please, now.  And also, while they are here, why don't they have a look at his wares?

rows: Alchemist's Ring
When the wearer of this ring imbibes a healing potion, they receive an additional {@dice 1d6} HP.
All-or-Nothing Coin
Once per day, instead of rolling a {@dice d20}, you can flip a coin. Heads=critical hit, tails=critical fail.
Anti-Gravity Sphere
A small fist-sized glass ball filled with a silvery smoke. When the sphere is destroyed, it disables the effect of gravity on everything in a 30ft radius.
Arcane Trickster's Glove

This glove turns your "Mage Hand" spell invisible, allowing you to perform stealthy actions, such as pickpocketing, slight-of-hand, or other acts of remote legerdemain. For these checks, use your Arcana score, instead of Stealth or Slight of Hand.
Astral Shell
A conch shell that allows you to interrogate the souls of the recently dead.
Billow Branch
A cool vaping pen that you can use once per day to gain advantage on either Persuasion or Intimidation checks.
Champion's Belt

This ornate belt is given to someone who has bested all opponents in a test of strength. Once per day the wearer may substitute their Strength score for their Wisdom or Charisma when making a stat check.
Kirkland Comb of Come Back Any Time

For the low low price of 100 gp, this comb could be yours! From the brand you trust, this signature Kirklands Comb of Come Back Anytime will fulfill all your interdimensional repeat-customer needs! Swipe it through your hair and you and any adjacent willing creatures will be magically transported back to the {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x} pocket dimension.
Diadem of Fabulous Truthiness

Once per long rest, you can channel your terminal fabulously into this simple circlet and cast a free "{@spell Zone of Truth}", limited to a single target rather than a radius. Confound your enemies, emasculate your friends, and free up your cleric's spell slots so he can do some actual healing.
Extreme Teen Bible
A +1 Holy Symbol. The cover features a rad skateboarder. Allows the user to more easily spread the good word of your deity to teens.
Flaming Poisoning Raging Sword of Doom
A sword with a gigantic blade, wreathed in flames and with a crooked, oozing scorpion's stinger affixed to its point. Deals an extra 20 Melee Damage.
Glasses of Lightning Comprehension
Allows you to read and absorb written information in a language you understand ten times as fast.
Glutton's Fork

Once a day this fork will allow the user to eat any non-magical item they can fit in their mouth and gain {@dice 2d6} HP. Just tap the fork on the item and it will turn edible. Once eaten, a transformed item is {@i gone forever}. Probably.
Grappling Hook
Once a day, you can shoot a grappling hook across a gap, up wall, or use it to help traverse other obstacles.
Haunted Doll
This doll is very creepy. If its owner ever fails a third death save, the doll will take the hit instead, and will die in place of its owner.
Immovable Rod

This rod is a flat iron bar with a small button on one end. When the button is pushed (a move action), the rod does not move from where it is, even if staying in place defies gravity. Thus, the owner can lift or place the rod wherever they wish, push the button, and let go. Several immovable rods can even make a ladder when used together (although only two are needed). An immovable rod can support up to 8,000lbs before falling to the ground. If a creature pushes against an immovable rod, it must make a DC 30 Strength check to move the rod up to 10ft in a single round.
Jar of Bees
A literal jar of bees. You could probably throw it at enemies or through a window and create a distraction. Or you could drop it like a dumb-dumb and get stung a bunch.
The Kiss the Cook Grill Master Edition Grill

The Kiss The Cook Grill Master Edition Grill has no peers when it comes to grilling meats n' good eats. This item can be used to cook meat, which must be hunted, during a short or long rest. Anyone in your party who eats this delicious meat will gain {@dice 1d8} temporary hit points after completing the rest. Shrinks to fit in your pocket when not in use.
Lens of Straight Creepin'
Once per day allows you to see the footprints, tracks, or markings of anything that moved through the observed area recently.
Magnetic Charge

A fist-sized glass ball with a blue button on top. Once the button is pressed, the ball will begin to glow and produce a magnetic field that lasts two rounds of combat. The field repels any metal objects within 10ft of the ball. One charge per day.
Mathias the Living Grimoire Owl

This clockwork owl has been owned by dozens of different wizards throughout its lifetime and can now recite arcane knowledge on command. All Arcana checks made by the player who owns this item gain advantage. In addition, the player can use the owl to prepare a spell they do not know once per day. The spell still takes up a spell slot of the spell's level.
Mystery Powder
A bag of powder with one charge per day. When used on a creature, you roll {@dice 1d100}, and have the effect chosen from the "{@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB}" table.
Nitpicker

Resembles a miniature garden gnome that carries lock picking tools in his hands. When not in use, looks like a 4" inch tall statue. Once a day, he can be placed in front of a locked object, at which point the statue comes to life in order to attempt to pick the lock, rolling with a +10 to use his Thieves Tools. While picking the lock, the Nit Picker critiques any or all members of the party on their recent performance in the campaign. Nothing escapes the critical eye of the Nit Picker, no matter how small the perceived offence. Afterward, it reverts back to an inanimate statue.
No-Sodium Salt Shaker

This might look like a simple salt shaker, but the contents have been bewitched to turn a bright shade of pink if sprinkled over food or drink that contains poison. Also makes food taste good, as it's a delicious spice.
Phantom Fist
Makes your unarmed strikes more powerful and grants them the ability to knock enemies backwards. Adds {@dice 1d4} Damage to unarmed strikes and knocks back 10ft on hit.
Phone-a-Friend Scrying Bones

Once per day, can be used to ask a yes, no, or maybe question to the fates (DM). There are three bones carved into people with happy faces and sad faces. All happy faces means yes, all sad faces mean no, anything in between means maybe. The DM can respond or choose not to answer.
Plastic Sheriff Badge
Adds +3 to Deception checks when impersonating a person of authority.
Pocket Spa
A pocket-sized tent that inflates to normal size upon use (four people can fit within). Short rests taken within will grant an extra {@dice 1d8} HP.
Pocket Workshop

From the makers of the Pocket Spa, comes the Pocket Workshop. A top-of-the-line Craftsman woodworking shop concealed within a battered red toolbox. When opened, the toolbox reveals a descending staircase that leads to a pocket dimension containing your deluxe Craftsman workshop. Your workshop is well-lit, properly ventilated, and equipped with saws, planes, lathes, and dozens of hand tools. Everything you need to make your project a success. The workshop is always stocked with the highest quality wood from across the realms, as well as nutritious snacks and refreshments.
Ring of Channel Changing'
The wearer of the ring ({@i cough A PALADIN cough}) can activate it to change their Channel Divity ability to that of any other paladin oath, once a day.
Rickle Axager's Pocket Guide to Adventuring (3rd Edition)

Once per day, you can read a section on an associated skill check. For the next 24 hours, you have advantage on that skill check. Sections can also be read aloud to give an advantage to another party member.
Ring of Pointing
Copper ring with an inlaid ruby that shoots a laser out. It can be used as a distraction or to highlight salient information during business presentations.
Ring of Recall
This ring has 3 charges per day which can be spent to recover the slot used on a failed spell. A 3rd level spell costs 3 charges, 2nd level costs 2, and 1st level costs 1.
Ring of "I Would Like to Rage"
The wearer of this ring ({@i cough A BARBARIAN cough}) regains an expended rage slot once a day.  But they have to politely say "I would like to rage." for it to take effect.
Ring of "Yes We Can-trip"

The wearer of this ring can perform any cantrip on their class's spell list, even ones they don't know. That's right, any. BUT, they have to announce "YES WE CAN-TRIP" in order for their cantrip to succeed.
Rusted Can of Cheerwine
Has seen some shit, but seems to be radiating with vital energies. Grants +5 to Max HP. Brewed in beautiful Atlanta, Georgia. Probably. I don't know. I'm making that up.
Scuttlebuddy

A mechanical beetle you can use as a spy. An earpiece included to listen in from up to 100ft away. Cannot collect items or interact with environment. It's very fragile; it can be broken easily if discovered and breaks after four total uses.
Shield of Heroic Memories

This perfectly round silver shield initially has a mirror finish. As a hero takes it into battle, it remembers the enemies encountered, gaining a +1 AC on any subsequent battle with creatures of that type. The events of the battle are intricately engraved onto the shield's surface (which has a seemingly endless capacity for detail). The bearer of the shield may also attempt to recount past battles (real or imagined) to the shield. Upon a DC 10 Charisma check (real) or DC 15 Deception check (imagined), the shield confers a +1 AC against the creatures described in the tall tales. Three failed attempts at recounting stories cause the shield to be cleared of all of its memories; the engravings disappear, it reverts to its mirror finish, and all bonuses are lost.
Slicer of T'pire Weir Isles
This item is useless, but with a good enough sales pitch (Persuasion check), you can convince anyone of its value and get them to trade you their most valuable possession for it.
Stones of Farspeech
Walkie talkies, basically. Range of five miles. 200 gp each.
Strongmouse's Laughing Amulet

Traditionally worn by high priests of the boisterous and jovial smiling god, the amulet carries the stylised image of a human face, mouth open in laughter. Whenever a foe is defeated, the wearer may activate the amulet by tapping it twice and then delivering the best taunting joke or victorious one-liner applicable to the current situation. If the jest pleases Strongmouse (DM), he rewards the adventurer by recharging up to {@dice 1d10}+CON HP. But Strongmouse is a fickle God; jokes that fail are punished with a small bolt of lightning, dealing {@dice 1d6} Lightning Damage per failure.
Tankard of Potent Drink
Makes alcoholic drinks more potent; but, if you drink water from it, you immediately become sober.
Tarantula Bracelet

Once per day, this bracelet bestows "{@spell Spider Climb}" on the wearer for 10 minutes and renders their movement while climbing completely silent, giving them advantage on Stealth checks. I want to be explicitly clear: there's no web slinging. YOU WILL SLING NO WEBS. But you will climb, and slime, just like a spider can.
Throwing Shield

Confers the same AC bonus as a regular shield, and can be used as a thrown weapon. Can travel IN A STRAIGHT LINE up to 30ft, and deals {@dice 1d8}+STR Damage. IT DOESN'T COME BACK TO YOU AFTERWARDS. AND DON'T TRY TO RICOCHET THIS SHIT.
Tim Tebow's Ring
When worn, anything you can pick up and fit in your hand you can throw in a perfect spiral pass up to 100 yards.
Unlimited Pasta Pass
Can be used at any participating Olive Garden for free unlimited pasta for the owner of the pass and free soft drinks for their guests.
Virtuoso's Mask
Allows you to cast "{@spell Disguise Self}" as a Cantrip instead of a 1st Level Spell.
Wand of Switcheroo

When pointed at a creature of similar size within 100ft, the holder will switch places with that target, if it is willing. If it is unwilling, it must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution save to resist. One charge per long rest.
Wordonomicon

A dictionary with three blank spaces that can be filled in to magically create words that will instantly be assimilated into the common tongue as if they always existed.  After 3 uses, the Wordonomicon is full and can't be used again.

entries.name: Making Deals for "Precious Things"
entries: If adventures haven't the coin, Garfield is willing to accept other forms of payment, from favors to XP.  Below are some suggested "precious things" the heroes may be willing to part with, and their suggested value to Garfield.

entries.name: Suggested Values of "Precious Things"
rows: Memories/Experience
1 XP
1 gp
Life Blood
1 Permanent Point of Max HP
100 gp
Trade Skill
1 Language or Tool Proficiency
100 gp
Natural Talent
1 Skill Proficiency, ex: Stealth
Ability
1 Ability Point (ability cannot be reduced below 10)
Unique Skill
1 Feat
Special Favor
The character will be summoned to perform some kind of task for Garfield at a time of his choosing. (See: "{@area Special Favors for Garfield|442|x}" below.)
Negotiable

entries: Tip: create a character sheet for Garfield and anything the players trade away, literally add it to his stats. You can (and should!) even let this drive the demand for certain offerings, for ex: if he's already maxed out his CHA score, he's not interested in any CHA points in trade.

Note that while Garfield will accept these precious things as payment, he will {@i never} give them or sell them back. The only thing he will offer as payment for players' items is good ol' fashioned gold pieces. Remember, as with most merchants, Garfield will only offer to buy an item for half its real value (gotta make a profit, am I right?).

entries.name: Special Favors for Garfield
entries: If a character opts to enter a pact with Garfield as part of a deal, they are bound to uphold their end of the bargain: performing a special favor for Garfield at a time of his choosing.

The favor could be as simple as "chop this wood", or "solve this riddle", or more complex and grim such as "you must betray your ally in combat", perhaps meaning the PC's next attack or spell must target a fellow party member. The terms of the deal are totally up to the DM's creativity, but the difficulty of the task should reflect the amount of gold bargained for. As a baseline example, the gp value of a "chop this wood"-level task might be 100 gp, as it would be little more than a 1 to 2 round distraction during combat and some ATH checks. But a more serious and difficult favor like "convince this powerful mage to incinerate this small village" might be well worth 1000 gp or more.

Regarding the "time of his choosing", it should be understood that the timing will almost certainly be suboptimal for the character. The obvious choice for the DM being during combat or an important social encounter. When the PC has completed the task, they are returned. Or, if their task requires them to be transported back before completing it (such as in a "you must attack your ally" scenario), then some sort of punishment for failure must be imposed. Suggestion: Garfield immediately takes an amount of the character's XP equal to the value of the failed favor.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: When the party is ready to depart, if they haven't purchased a "Kirkland Comb of Come Back Any Time", Garfield informs them that they will find a scratch n' sniff patch on the back of his business card which, as a one-time courtesty, will transport them back to {@area Fantasy Costco|437|x}.

Before he casts the teleport spell to whisk them back to their realm, he also subtly reminds them that time flows a bit differently here, and there's no guarantee how much time will have passed when they return.
When the party is sent back, ideally a few days or even weeks should have passed. Read the following aloud upon their departure:

Still holding Pocket, the tressym kitten, in one hand, with the other Garfield the Deals Warlock draws a sigil in the air and utters something in an arcane language. A glowing ball of light soon speads across the stone wall behind you, and the familiar swirling blue vortex forms in its center.
"Thank you for shopping at Fantasy Costco, where all your dreams come true! Come back anytime! Taa!"

You step through the portal, feeling the same tingling sensation as you did when you first arrived.  When you step out, the grass beneath your feet softly crunches.  You look around and see that you are a few hundred yards from the open pasture where the carnival was once set up, now empty grassland again, devoid of all the whimsical theater and lively atmosphere.  Trees which had moved out to make room for the carnival have now resettled in their old spots, and the lazy river encircling the fair grounds is now gone.

During the time the heroes were gone, the Witchlight Carnival has packed up and left town, and Madryk Roslof has passed away.  If the party goes back to check on him, his assistant, Orsen, has already cleared out the body, and informs you that the memorial is tomorrow. This gives players an opportunity to ceremoniously give back his ring, as a sign of respect, perhaps placing it on his mantle, or even by attending the memorial and slipping it on his finger. Award XP for good RP and good will.

With the carnival and Madryck gone, the adventurers will be back to their main quests in no time.  They should still have {@footnote a way to revisit Fantasy Costco|The characters should have either purchased a Kirkland Comb of Come Back Anytime, or have been informed of the one-time-use scratch n' sniff on the back of Garfield's business card, either of which can transport them back to Fantasy Costco at will. Remember that when they return from the pocket dimension, the exact location and time in which they are deposited is unpredictable.} and its oddball warlock merchant when they need to.  And even though they cannot revisit the carnival for 8 more years, they will never forget the dazzling spectacles and whimsical characters, and, if one or more of them were crowned the Witchlight Monarch, they will always have their illusory tiara to remind them!
